Merge pull request #4708 from jfdm/show-visibility-in-docs

Show visibility in doc comments.
Updated changelog and add GitHub issue reference: Fixes #4702

Add an alternative stack configuration file to deal with upstream GHC issues.

There is an upstream issue with GHC on some Ubuntu and Fedora machines.
The issue is that for GHC versions greater than 8.4.X linking to libFFI is broken.
See the following GHC issue page for more information:

  <https://gitlab.haskell.org/ghc/ghc/issues/15397>

This means that an Idris built with `libFFI` support will fail at runtime as the executable would not be able to find the correct `libffi` shared object.
This will cause the build to fail.

This commit adds an alternative stack configuration file to help bypass the issues for those affected by the issue.
Bump stack to latest version.
Amended the test suite to report updated documentation.

Show visibility in doc comments.

Currently the result of `:doc` displays totality information for functions.
However there are two scenarios where having the accessiblity/visibility information would be beneficial:

1. Type-level computations failing to reduce.

A computed value in your type might fail to reduce in the definition of the computing function is not public c.f. exportation of functions computing type synonyms.
A good numpty check would be to add this information to the doc output, much as we do for totality status.

2. Working with 'Exported' constructors.

Much like exported functions, some data types might be exported rather than public exported.
One has to assert the functions visibility by checking the source code, this is cumbersome.

This commit adds visibility status to the documentation output.
Such that if totality information is to be displayed we output the totality and accessibility information, otherwise we just output the accessibility information.
Simplify reverse proofs

Unlike clang, GCC doesn't support unicode identifiers.

Fixes #4698

Add Clock/clockTime in System

This is for getting the time at a finer granularity than seconds. I
want this for getting approximate wall clock time measurements for run
time of fragments of programs, so the interface is very basic, but I am
open to better, more sophisticated APIs!

I expect this won't work on Windows, so it's #ifdefed out and always
returns 0. If you know how to fix this, please do!

Fix potential memory error on tail calls

SLIDE needs to use 'memmove' rather than 'memcpy' because in the case
that the called function has more arguments than the current stack
frame, the regions will overlap, which would lead to undefined
behaviour.

Merge pull request #4687 from martinbaker/myDoc

rewrite documentation for interactive theorem proving

Initial transfer of {AS} grammar to Sphinx Documtation.

When {AS} originally moved Idris' parser from parsec to Trifecta, a grammar describing the surface syntax was contributed as source code comments.
This is good for developers, but not necessarily helpful for those not wanting to have a reference.
Given that we have moved documentation from LaTeX to sphix-doc we can leverage the `productionlist` environment to provide a clickable grammar.

I have split the grammar into sections, but over time this should be pruned, sorted, and formatted properly.
Further I think a good contribution would be to merge this file with the proceeding section to provide examples alongside.
It might be work spinning out these sections as a top level document in its own right, with the 'Language Reference' being placed as a 'Idris Tooling Guide'.

Prove that multiplication of inverses is the same os multiplication of original elements.
Prove that multiplication by a negative makes the result also negative.

Prove some most basic laws of abstract algebra:

    * the inverse of neutral element is the neutral element itself
    * the inverse composed with itself is identity
    * the inverse operation distributes over addition
    * the neutral element of addition is the absorbing element of
      multiplication (both on the left and right hand side)

Merge pull request #4670 from melted/binary_win

Make binary files the default when opening.

Make binary files the default when opening.

The reason is that most things on windows handles unix line endings just
fine and this leads to terrible bugs when writing binary files.

fopen still allows opening of files without the "b".

This only has effect on Windows, but POSIX systems allows the "b" as a
noop.

This saves rechecking a file if none of its imports have the same
interfaces and there are otherwise no changes.

The hash function is probably quite bad, so if you know how to do a
better one please consider contributing it! Also, this makes an already
terrible piece of code in Parser.hs even worse (sorry) and it's crying
out for a refactoring if anyone has any enthusiasm for it (as is the
whole system of chasing dependencies and loading modules).

This is mostly to speed up development of Blodwen, which was really
starting to get painful when making small changes to core modules.

Wrap GMP operations in a requireAlloc

Since GMP uses the idris allocator, and when it uses it is out of our
control, we need to be sure it doesn't GC in the middle and move things
it's working with. I have merely guessed at an upper limit for what
it'll need. This is a horrible hack. Sorry. If you're working with
numbers that don't fit in 64k you might have problems...

newBuffer should return a managed pointer

Otherwise, we're just guessing on the size, and that way lies segfaults.
It turns out the size in Buffer.idr might have been correct once, but
isn't now, and so unless we're lucky registering the pointer will copy
memory we don't have access to. If the RTS does the registering of the
pointer, at least it knows the size.

(It's likely this is doable without the malloc, using iallocate
directly, but this required fewer changes.)

Use Integer comparison in Lexer for string length

Nat comparison isn't optimised, so it makes a massive different to
convert to Integer first. This should probably be addressed in the
longer term by having a better way to optimise Nats...

Merge pull request #4494 from jfdm/fix-nubbing

Why nub a list when you can use a set.

Why nub a list when you can use a set.

Highlighting information was contained in an association list. Not
only were there duplicates in the list, nubbing the list resulted in
performance losses on proper sized code bases.

We migrate the lists to sets and use `FC'` to ensure no false
positives are returned when comparing to elements in the list. `FC'`
is `FC` but with equality.

Anecdotal tests show good performance improvements wrt to code highlighting.

Tail calls via trampolines in C back end

This means we can turn off the clang optimiser and still have working
code generated. It does mean that the code generated is a bit slower
(there's a small overhead for the trampolines) but it compiles much
faster, which is a big deal for developing larger systems!

We need a way to turn the clang optimiser back on - probably just a
compiler flag.

Fix repetition in Idris Highlights.

Dumped highlighting information contains a lot of duplication. When
sending highlighting information make sure it is unique. This fix
simply nubs the list based on file position and output annotation to
ensure uniqness. Otherwise the Eq instance for FC defaults to true and
removes everything.

Faster dependency chasing

blocks) and a lot of the work it's doing is not actually necessary since
the primary goal is to find shadowed names. So, only search alternatives
if they are genuine alternatives rather than there for name
disambiguation.

some (smaller) performance problems too.

Reverse improvements (#4310)

* Expose helper for reverse.

Not only is it a useful function all its own, the lack of exposure prevented
any proofs about the behavior of reverse outside of Prelude.List.

* Fundamental properties for reverse and reverseOnto.

These are less proerties, and more specification.  These properties should be
sufficient for any proofs about the behavior of the functions, and any
implementations violating these properties would not generally be considered
correct.

* Some additional properties about reverse.

reverseAppend and reverseReverseId are proven in terms of the reverse
specification proeprties and should be robust against future implemetation
changes, or migration to a module separate from reverse.

reverseSingletonId is a trivial proof, but will likely need updating if it can
no longer "see" the reverse implemenation.

Fix looped temporary allocations in mini-GMP (#4324)

* Bump mini-gmp to the libgmp-6.1 version

* Add a test for #4311.

* Avoid looped temporary allocation in mini-gmp

Backport of https://gmplib.org/repo/gmp/rev/164971d5c8d0

mpn_div_qr_1_preinv function is called in a loop while converting mpz_t to a
string. Looped allocation causes garbage collection while still in mpz_get_str
for big enough numbers, which may cause wrong results or crashes.

Fixes #4311.

Set C language standard to C99 in runtime and codegen (#4308)

* Fix tests for compilation under Windows

C preprocessor tests for detecting Windows were inconsistent across
the code base, and in some cases wrong. This change makes the
detection uniform and correct at all places.

* Write `usleep` in terms of `nanosleep`

`usleep` is deprecated and a compiler warning is issued if it's used
with a POSIX compiler flag set. As an added bonus, it's range has been
increased.

* Set C language standard to C99 in runtime and codegen

Currently the exact C language used by the runtime and the C code
generator is not set and therefore different compilers may use
different standards depending on their default behaviour. This may
lead to inconsistencies in builds, such a sucessful build in one
machine failing in another.

Fix binding rules in patterns

Names should only be implicitly bound in patterns if they begin with a
lower case letter or _ (as in types), and we've always documented this
but never actually enforced it! This has led to some mysterious and
undetected bugs in Idris programs.

This is likely to break some code (sorry) given that I've had to update
a few tests to follow the new rules. However, the code it breaks is code
that shouldn't have worked in the first place!

Merge pull request #4182 from msmorgan/text-token

Text.Token: token utilities for lexing and parsing

Improve error message locations (#4210)



This contribution uses the strict WriterT transformer over our parser stack with a
monoid over FC and what used to be spanFC to compute the span of
non-terminal parsers from the spans of trackExtent-wrapped parsers.

The net result is that the locations reported for errors and warnings is
much improved. Most errors now report the extent of the error, rather than a
point roughly preceeding it (or after it, sometimes). There are still cases
where FCs are recomputed as a point after parsing--I didn't fix these, to cut
the scope of this PR--though all file locations produced during parsing use
the new, spanning parsing combinators.

I would start reading at Idris.Parser.Stack, then Idris.Parser.Helpers.

Overview:    
- *FC and non-*FC parsers (e.g. tokenFC and token, charLiteralFC and
    charLiteral, etc.) have been elided and the FC suffix removed. Any
    parser can be asked to report it's FC using the extent or withExtent
    combinators.
    
- Extents reported for errors end at the last character of the token, rather
    than on the following character.
 
- Now that all parsers can be queried for their spans, highlighting is
    done with the highlight parser combinator, e.g.
    highlight AnnQuasiquote (symbol "`{{" ...). These can be nested.
   
- Totality checking, in its current design, reports the extent of the first
    equation. This is a bit more misleading now that the span is computed
    correctly, since it could look like it's trying to indicate which clause is
    non-total. We should fix this (hopefully as a separate PR.)
   
- The span of clauses is actually the span of the right-hand side, and so this
    is reported when there is an error on the right-hand side or the left-hand
    side. We should also fix this (hopefully as a separate PR.)
    
- There's probably cases where, owning to the improved granularity, we will now
    notice errors were reported with FCs from the wrong object.
    I haven't tested an IDE-mode client yet. They may need to be patched if they
    are manually excluding the last character of tokens. Highlighting appears to
    work fine without changes, though.

This improves the output of the REPL command `:printdef Prelude.List.length`,
which previously showed as the following:
```
Idris> :printdef Prelude.List.length
length : List a -> Nat
length [] = PE_fromInteger_dc75de74 0
length (x :: xs) = PE_+_6b31ad5c (PE_fromInteger_dc75de74 1) (length xs)
```

Signed-off-by: Michael Morgan <morgan.michael@me.com>
add test cases verifying new verbatim string behavior
update CHANGELOG.md with new verbatim string behavior

support trailing quotes in verbatim string literals

Since verbatim strings in Idris don't support escapes, it seems appropriate
to have them consume all '"' characters before the closing "\"\"\"". This is
the approach taken by Scala.

This means the following verbatim strings now parse, and produce the parenthesized
values, which are expressed as standard strings.
* `"""""""` (`"\""`)
* `""""hello""""` (`"\"hello\""`)

Text.Lexer: toTokenMap utility function

Converts a list of `(Lexer, k)` into a `TokenMap (Token k)`.

Text.Parser: add `match` function for easier terminals

In a grammar that accepts `Token k` as its token type, `match` reduces the
boilerplate required to parse terminals.

Instead of requiring a terminal parsing function per token (or token kind)
with a case split, this function requires an `Eq` implementation to compare kinds
of tokens.

Text.Token: utilities for token value conversion

This module contains:

* `Token` - This record type is parameterized by some type `k`. It holds a
  value of type `k` representing the kind of token that was recognised, along
  with the text that was recognised for this particular `Token`.

* `TokenKind` - Implementing this interface for some type `k` allows the user to
  specify how the recognised text from a token should convert into a value.
  There are two functions in the interface.
    * `tokType` - Determines the type that a recognised string should convert
      into for this kind of token.
    * `tokValue` - Given a kind and a string, convert the string into a value of
      the correct type.

Using `Token k` as the token input to your grammar (and output of your lexer)
allows for a couple advantages.

1. When a new kind of token is added, the compiler no longer accepts the program
   until it is accounted for in the `TokenKind` implementation.
2. The information about the recotnised text is kept for as long as possible.
   Since it's stored on the `Token` record, you don't lose information about the
   recognised text until a parse rule succeeds.

Text.Lexer: deprecate `manyTill`

There is no exact replacement, but the behavior of `manyTill` is
inconsistent with what's expected from a lexer library that supports
lookahead. It consumes its terminator, but it's okay if it never sees
its terminator and the input ends instead.

Text.Lexer: add newline and comment lexers

Adds `newline`, `newlines`. They recognise "\r\n", "\r", or "\n" as a newline.

Adds `blockComment` and `lineComment`.

Text.Lexer: add `manyUntil` and `manyThen`

These new functions utilise lookahead to non-greedily consume a
sub-lexer until an endpoint lexer is recognised.

`manyUntil` does not consume the end lexer, and `manyThen` does.

Text.Lexer: fix behavior of `surround`

`manyTill` is a `Recognise False`. It will recognise either nothing,
or any number of `l` followed by an `end`. This makes it unsuited for
`surround`, because the end character is required.
Text.Lexer: refactoring

Text.Parser: implement `Functor (Grammar tok c)`

Also included:

* Operators `(<*>)`, `(<*)`, `(*>)`, analogous to those defined by
  the `Applicative` interface.

* The functions `join` and `choice`, which resemble `Prelude.Monad.join`
  and `Prelude.Applicative.choice`.

Text.Lexer: add quantified lexer combinators

Add new combinators that allow for counted sub-lexer repetition.
This includes the combinators `atLeast`, `atMost`, `between`, and `exactly`.

Text.Lexer: improve `choice`

Removed constraint requiring a non-empty list. Now, `choice` always
fails if the list is empty.

Text.Lexer: fix `reject` behavior at end-of-input

Previously, `reject` was implemented using `expect`, and inverting the
predicate used with `Pred`. This means that `reject` would fail if it's the
final lexer in the input, instead of succeeding like it should.

To fix this, the constructor `Expect` was renamed to `Lookahead`, with a new
boolean argument indicating positive or negative lookahead. This boolean is
processed in `scan`. Now, `reject` succeeds if the sub-lexer fails for any
reason, including end of input.

Text.Lexer: add surround, quote, and escape

`surround` and `quote` are both for sequences of lexers between
existing lexers. `surround` is for when the lexers at the start and end
are different, and `quote` is for when they are the same.

`escape` recognises any single escape character followed by a sub-lexer.

Existing combinators were written in terms of these new ones where it
made sense.

remove Interfaces.Zippable in favor of Interfaces.Correlative

Correlative is a sub-interface of Functor with a single operator `(</>)`,
with the same signature as `Prelude.Applicative.(<*>)`. The difference is
that a Correlative functor must apply operations element-by-element to matching
elements. Many Applicative implementations already work in this way, but
notably List does not (it uses the Cartesian product).

The name "Naperian" was suggested for this concept, but I was unable to find
any accessible literature indicating that this nomenclature would be correct.

Merge pull request #3986 from jfdm/fix-literate-module

Fix line number reporting for `Text.Literate`.

Fix line number reporting for `Text.Literate`.

Ensures that the line count of the original document and resulting
code file are kept the same. This is important for reporting errors
from the code in the original document. Unfortunatly, column numbers
for line markers are not preserved and differ by one plus the number
of characters in the used line marker.

Merge pull request #3985 from jfdm/literate-module

Addition of tools to help with literate source files.

Addition of a literate tooling to `contrib`.

`Text.Literate` is a simple Idris module to help with processing
literate document, and returning the raw code.

The tooling is markup language and code agnostic, and uses
user-defined 'styles' to identify code blocks in the presented text
document. This allows literate styles to be constructed that respect
the host markup language's conventions.

The underlying tokeniser is also greedy. Once it identifies a line
marker it reads until the end of line, and once it recognises a start
block, it will consume until the next identifiable end block. Thus the
input literate files must be well-formed w.r.t to line markers and
code blocks.

Merge pull request #3826 from david-christiansen/feature/present-names

Support presentations of abstract names in output

Support presentations of abstract names in output

When Idris sends strings over the IDE protocol, it includes
out-of-band semantic information that allows regions of the string to
_represent_ their underlying data. In particular, terms are serialized
and sent with their representations, allowing things like interactive
error messages in IDE clients.

This patch adds a similar capability for names. Now, serialized
datatypes are sent with names, allowing names that don't have syntax
to be the subjects of commands. This is very convenient when working
with metaprogramming or debugging the compiler.

The change is backwards-compatible, because it has to be enabled in
each IDE client, and if they aren't sent serialized names, then they
don't act differently from today.

Add implementation of `VerifiedSemigroup Nat`, and others along the same lines, all in contrib.

New interfaces and implementations in contrib, building up the coverage of `Verified` implementations which provide proof terms to witness that the base instance obeys the appropriate laws.  Includes a back-compatibility breakage - demotion of the instance of `Semigroup Nat` into a named instance.

Example: `VerifiedSemigroup Nat` contains a witness for associativity of the operation defined in `Semigroup Nat`.

- New implementations of algebraic interfaces for numeric types, for example SemiGroup for multiplication on Nat (as well as addition).  ZZ now has the whole numeric tower covered up to `RingWithUnity` - ditto Nat where appropriate.

- All these instances now have `Verified` counterparts as well (libs/contrib/Interfaces/Verified.idr), for example the instance `[PlusNatSemiV] VerifiedSemigroup Nat` extends `[PlusNatSemi] Semigroup Nat` with a member that is a proof term `semigroupOpIsAssociative`.

- Some non-numeric `Verified` interfaces and instances are added too - for example `VerifiedFunctor Maybe`.  There are TODO placeholders for extending coverage further (`VerifiedFunctor List` for example).

- Back-compatibility break in contrib: in libs/contrib/Control/Algebra/NumericImplementations.idr, the `Semigroup Nat` instance is demoted into a named instance called `PlusNatSemi`.  This puts it on a par with the new `MultNatSemi`.  Similarly `Monoid Nat`, `SemiGroup ZZ` and `Monoid ZZ`.

Handle idris_mkFileError through a special-case.

Use a dirty IORef to simulate C's errno behaviour. If an exception
occurs during fileOpen, then store a FileError expression, which is read
and returned in a later call to idris_mkFileError.

As a result of this change, file errors generated during the execution
of a type provider, for example file not found, will be correctly
reported. Previously the interpreter crashed.

Add note on Effects to ST tutorial
Add network example to ST tutorial
Add section on composing state machines

Change meaning of 'data' in interfaces

A "data" declaration in an interface means "this must be implemented by
something injective, so that unification can determine the arguments".

This is slightly weaker than the existing definition, which required the
definition to be an actual data type. It means that unification can
learn less, but it is far more useful in practice, it turns out.

This breaks the interfaces005 test, but it is not clear that this test
is testing something that we want to do, and if we do want to do it, we
can do it a different way...
Add to ST tutorial for Control.ST.call

No need for labels to be polymorphic in ST

Just use Var - this is what 'new' creates and there's no way they can be
anything else. So use 'Var' specifically, which makes inference easier
elsewhere.

Add ST tutorial section on DataStore interface
Add 'remove' for naming consistency

It is mostly there to help with interactive development - you can see
what the states should be before returning the value by writing

```sh

```
Update ST error reflection for STransLoop

Allow more context manipulation in ST

It's usually a good idea for an API to put newly created things at the
end of the resource list because this means 'updateWith' doesn't shuffle
things around too much, so make it easier to manipulate the context by
moving resources to the end, with 'toEnd'.

Fixes #3491

Careful when expanding dsl notation

If an expansion of a lambda contains a lambda, for example, we shouldn't
expand forever, so only expand the original, rather than the result of

Fixes #3477

Fix 'interp' sample

I don't think these samples are well maintained - I should either go
through all of them and fix them, or remove them completely in favour of
the idris-demos repo.

Deal with ambiguity in impossible clauses

Some things were getting past totality checking because we weren't
generating clauses when there was ambiguity on a non-checkable lhs. Now
take a type-directed approach to building the term for the case tree
which, even though it can't be checked, at least has the right
unambiguous names.

If we can't resolve the ambiguity, it's an error. In some (probably
rare) cases this might need the programmer to disambiguate explicitly. I
think this is a price worth paying for soundness...

Fixes #3269

Add regression test for #3651.

Resolves #3651.

Another scoped implicit fix

When checking that an implicit argument exists, we need to do this after
inserting scoped implicits, not before, in case more arise by expanding
types.

Fix disambiguation on LHS

There was a potential problem with ambiguity on the LHS with forced
patterns, since the disambiguation happened at the wrong time. Any list
of alternatives with PHidden need to have the PHidden lifted out.

Use offset for substr if possible

If the substring is a suffix, use a pointer to the existing string
rather than constructing a new string.

Add StringBuffer to Prelude.Strings

This allows building up a large string through a series of IO operations
without reallocating every time. We can use this, for example, to
implement readFile better.

Also: added prim__readChars which reads a specific number of characters
from a file (truncates if they aren't available), updated readFile to
use the new primitives, and brought the Executor up to date with new
primitives.

Fixes #3602
Also look for nodejs in addition to node in the testsuite

Take some more care with forcing

If the forced name is only forceable because we've reduced a name, and
that name isn't exported, then we can't actually get the name in other
modules! So, check for forceable names before reducing the type, not
after.

(We could do a bit better than this, in fact, and reduce names which are
public export, but there isn't a huge benefit to this at the moment so
I'll save it for later.)

Allow explicit arguments for scoped implicits

Along with other recent patches, this fixes #3654, by allowing explicit
arguments to be given for named scoped implicits in the same way as for
top level implicits.

Fix delab of scoped implicits

We shouldn't display implicit arguments as explicit arguments, so we
need to keep track of the current environment to know what the implicit
arguments are to locally defined names.

Fix for implicits in records

Since we have this annoying distinction between top level implicits and
scoped implicits, we need to make sure that things are marked
appropriately. So when we parse record fields, they become scoped
implicits.

(I don't think there is really a need for this distinction, but because
implicits were top level only at first, it's hard to unify everything.
One for the next rewrite, should it ever happen, I suppose...)

(Sorry! Not in the habit yet...)

Fix variable elaboration

Variable elaboration is a bit tricky because of unbound implicits and
types and needing to bind pattern variables.

This lifts out the elaborator for references to *defined* variables
(i.e. once we know it's not a pattern variable/implicit) into a common
place. As a result, it fixes an issue with scoped implicits where they
weren't being applied properly, and allows us to remove a hack (which I
didn't properly understand but as a result of this fix, I do now...)

Add Control.ST.Exception

Only possible to throw exceptions after all the state transitions have
been done, meaning that we always know everything is in the final state
when we get to the catch block.

This is most likely to be useful for controlling things, such as
backtracking parsers, so it's possible that 'Exception' is not really
the right name for it. However...

Add runAs to Control.ST

This allows us to get at the underlying monad, if we know what it is,
which makes it possible to implement things like exceptions

part 2 of FORCE_ALIGNMENT fix for arduino targets.

When FORCE_ALIGNMENT was introduced for pointer aligment on 8-bit arduino targets (See idris-lang@47cd264) it was not applied to the initialization of the cheney algorithm during garbage collection. The fix modifies the start of the heap location in the same way the FORCE_ALIGNMENT-define does for the initialization of the FP-heap in alloc_heap(...) in file idris_heap.c.

To prevent duplicate code this logic has been put in the function aligned_heap_pointer(...) in the idris_heap.c module and included here.

C style changes while porting rts to 9front (#3596)

* Avoid pointer arithmetic on void pointers

The C standard doesnâ€™t allow pointer arithmetic with void pointers.
However, in GNU C it is allowed by considering the size of void is 1.

http://gcc.gnu.org/onlinedocs/gcc/Pointer-Arith.html

Below is an excerpt from http://stackoverflow.com/a/3855633

Per the online C standard (n1256 draft):

    6.2.5 Types
    ...
    27 A pointer to void shall have the same representation and alignment requirements as a pointer to a character type.

* Using void for functions without arguments

Using void foo(void) instead of void foo() for functions without
arguments, as per http://stackoverflow.com/a/693794

* Avoid pointer arithmetic on void pointers in the C generated code

Improved User facing progress reporting.

Idris' output has been updated to more accurately reflect its
progress through the compiler i.e. Type Checking; Totality Checking;
IBC Generation; Compiling; and Code Generation. To control the
loudness of the reporting three verbosity levels are introduced:
`--V0`, `--V1`, and `--V2`. The old aliases of `-V` and `--verbose`
have been retained.

Merge pull request #3571 from jfdm/revert-verbosity

Reverted changes to verbosity reporting.

Fix for cyclic solutions in unifyProblems

If we get x=y and y=x, need to update the second from the result of the
first so that we don't solve holes that aren't actually solved yet. This
fixes one cause of the mysterious "No such variable" error by not
solving a hole with a variable that doesn't exist.
Fixes #2731

Errors for inspecting a _ in case/with

These are likely if checking something generated by interactive editing,
so it's better that we know about the possibility and report helpfully.
Fixes #3280
Reverted changes to verbosity reporting.

Account for 'let' with unbound implicits

Previously a 'let' in a type would be ignored for unbound implicits,
leading to strange behaviour when the name bound in the let would get
bound as an implicit argument too.

Fix patvar naming for implicits

There's no need to make the name unique if the pattern is going to have
the same name as the hole. Otherwise, this can cause problems under the
types of metavariables, where the name gets renamed and the generated
type is then no longer valid because there's an undefined name in it.
Fixes #3398

Fix enumFromThenTo

This worked in almost no cases... now uses a function to count with an
increment, and adds a test for ranges. Fixes #3512

Change evaluation of partial functions at REPL

To prevent infinite recursion at the REPL under binders, which results
in a neverending display of a diverging term, the evaluator at the REPL
will now block on a partial function when there is a free variable in
the context.

This means that you can still test partial functions at the REPL with
canonical values, but if they are recursive and non-terminating under
binders, you won't get infinite evaluation.

Fixes #3535

Add %used directive for idris_crash

Without it, it might fail to compile if there's a more complicated
message than just a string

Add 'idris_crash'

This is to abort immediately in the case of partial functions, and is
primarily to allow partial functions on primitives to have more useful
run time behaviour - an explicit crash is better than undefined
behaviour (as we've had up to now) with an inevitable unpredictable
crash or inexplicable behaviour.

Now used in strHead, strTail and strIndex, which were the main culprits,
and used for Debug.Error.error instead of an unsafePerformIO

Merge pull request #3551 from jfdm/improv-compiler-progress-reporting

Improve progress reporting.
Updated changelog.

Fix verbosity configuration error.

There was an existing 'logical' flaw for when to report progress.
When using a custom codegen (i.e. non-`C`), Idris would be verbose during
compilation even if no verbosity flag was set. For the default codegen
everything was non-verbose as expected: Type checking and parsing were not
verbosely reported.

The fix was to set the default verbosity to False. I suspect the error was
a result of the default codegen correctly setting verbosity to false, and
other codegen's weren't.

Improve progress reporting.

This commit improves the default progress reporting to clearly indicate at which stage Idris is during compilation.

For a simple hello world program with no dependencies, the output using `-V` will be:

```
$ idris Hello.idr -o a.out -V
Type checking ./Hello.idr
Totality checking ./Hello.idr
Writing IBC for: "./Hello.ibc"
Compiling Outut.
Generating Code.
```

Fix names in generating missing cases

They need to be unique throughout because when cases overlap, we may
want to match on the generated name (and this is a valid thing to do due
to, for example, fallthrough, where we might match on a thing more than
once).

Fixes #3524

Better choice of pattern to inspect in coverage

Add an 'Inferred' marker to TT, for building coverage trees only, which
means that patterns which were inferred by the machine rather than
written by the user are split later. This means that the coverage
checker will generate cases from user-written terms first, which
generally leads to more patterns being ruled out sooner.

Undo more liberal choice of forced arguments

While this Works On My Machine(tm), and there is no obvious reason why
it should behave differently on different machines, it causes an erasure
issue on Travis, so I'm undoing it until I work out what's going on.
Fix mistake in Data.hs

Coverage checker fix

If we've already explored an overlapping pattern, don't search further
down the case tree. Also check 'recoverability' of an error in the
coverage checker, rather than trusting the result from unification,
because more normalisation may have been possible since

Fix whnfArgs naming error

In particular, we need to be aware that names can be rebound in the
scope of whnfArgs, so don't instantiate the name after it's rebound.

New coverage checker

clauses from that, with some trickery to deal with overlapping cases.

that some existing programs will no longer compile, even if that is
unlikely. If such programs aren't fixable with extra "impossible" case
annotations, it may be a bug...

Fixes #2961.

Separate modules for termination/coverage

Move termination checking into its own module (Idris.Termination)
instead of having it as part of Idris.Coverage (which now just has
functions to generate clauses for coverage checking)

Look deeper when coverage checking

If there is a pattern variable with an obviously empty type, because all
of the constructors are in a different part of the family due to
disjoint indices, then reject the clause as impossible.

Speed up coverage checking

Once we've ruled out a clause, we can rule out any later clauses which
are a specialisation of that.

This helps with #3498, though there is no doubt still more we can do.

Remove a needless 'nub'

When generating cases for coverage checking, it doesn't help to remove
any repeats. Profiling shows that this achieves very little other than
taking a long time to run, and there are very few repeats anyway, so any
benefits are massively outweighed by the cost.

Fix logging of unfolds

Should fix the travis failure on GHC < 7.10

Apply forcing optimisation on LHS

This means that the case trees generated are much smaller, because we
don't bother matching on things we already know about.

Needs some care, because it affects some existing erasure results. For
the moment, we only force arguments when there's *no* occurrence of a
variable below a non-constructor name. This may be an issue with erasure
warnings rather than forcing, but it solves the problem for now.

Fixes #2657

Fix a source of major slowness

When we partially evaluate a definition, we need to know which names to
unfold (those that are part of the definition) so that we don't unfold
too much of the arguments in static position. We do this by searching
the call graph, which is really slow if we don't cache it. So, when we
elaborate a function with static arguments, now we cache it.

Remove unused case tree code

We now only need case trees for compile time and run time versions of a
definition
Merge branch 'master' of github.com:idris-lang/Idris-dev

Change totality checking and inlining

This solves a problem caused by inlining for totality checking, but not
elsewhere. For example, the following passes totality checking because x
is inlined:

foo = let x = diverging in 42

If we then assume it's safe to evaluate all parts of foo because it's
total, as the partial evaluator does, the compiler ends up in a loop.
So, the totality checked version and the stored version really need to
be the same, which this patch does.

We still need to do some controlled unfolding so that interface
dictionaries work correctly (controlled using the 'Unfold' flag on a
function), and to spot definitions which preserve
guardedness of productive definitions.

Elements of Fin when converted to Nat are smaller than the Bound. (#3407)

Updating range behavior to match Haskell's where appropriate

This resolves #3502 and resolves #3503. This also fixes the issue that natEnumFromThenTo could not descend.

I used make && make test on Ubuntu.

After adding the new tests, the existing implementation crashed.

    basic013:
Error: test/basic013
run: line 3: 19432 Segmentation fault      (core dumped) ./basic013
With the new implementation, all 202 tests passed.

I also built this on Windows, but was unable to run the tests, so I generated a stress test suite that passed range definitions to both Idris and Haskell to verify the output would be equivalent.

There's one notable difference from Haskell. In Haskell, ranges of the form [A,A..B] generate an infinite sequence of As. I chose to follow the existing implementation, which returns [] instead. This rule conflicts with another rule that ranges of the the form [A,B..A] return [A] in the case that B == A (i.e. the form [A,A..A]). My implementation returns [A] in that case.

Merge pull request #3436 from benjamin-hodgson/ghcjs-isWindows

Work around GHCJS's patched export of isWindows from System.FilePath

Work around GHCJS's patched export of isWindows from System.FilePath

Idris fails to compile under GHCJS because [GHCJS's System.FilePath
module](https://github.com/ghcjs/ghcjs-boot/blob/master/patches/filepath.patch)
exports an isWindows name. This clashes with Idris's internal
Util.System.isWindows function.

I've worked around this here by importing only the required names from
System.FilePath.

There's an [open issue](https://github.com/ghcjs/ghcjs-boot/issues/38)
in the GHCJS repository to fix this once and for all,
but since the issue has a simple workaround I thought I'd contribute
this patch to Idris too.

Merge pull request #3362 from jfdm/isolate-main

Tidying of `idrisMain` (fixes #1454).

Tidying of `idrisMain` (fixes #1454).

Introduction of a new module `Idris.Main` that contains the code
required to launch and run an interactive Idris session---compilation,
REPL et cetera. It has been spun out of `Idris.REPL`; common code has
been spun out from both into `Idris.ModeCommon`.

With `Idris.Main` comes a new entry point for Idris and presents
developers with a more unified API for running Idris programs. A side
affect of this approach is that the imports for codegens must be
changed to import `Idris.Main` and not `Idris.REPL`.

Merge pull request #3354 from bravit/fix/master/2884

Make totality checker to report partial functions correctly (fix #2884)

Make totality checker to report partial functions correctly (fix #2884)

Totality checker incorrectly reported some partial functions with complex
arguments (data constructors inside other data constructors) as total.
For example, these functions were considered total:

h : (Bool, Bool) -> Bool
h (True, x) = True
h (y, True) = True

data PP : Type where
  MkPP : Int -> PP

f : PP -> Bool
f (MkPP 0) = True
f (MkPP 1) = True
f (MkPP 2) = True

This commit fixes this and now such functions are reported as partial.
To fix this we generate more clauses which cover more possible cases.

Document the new test infrastructure

The file `test/README.md` details everything.
The `CHANGELOG` has been updated.

Hook the new test infrastructure to cabal

- A test hook in `Setup.hs` allows using the new test infrastructure with
  `cabal test`. Without it, cabal couldn't find the idris libraries.
- Make rules related to testing now call `cabal test`.
- The `test_timed` rule is removed because timings are given by default
- We introduce the `test_update` rule to update the golden files
- We introduce the `test_clean` rule to remove artifacts created when
  running the test suite. This is far from perfect ;
  a careful `git clean -f` should remove whatever is left
- The TEST-JOBS variable specifies the number of parallel jobs to
  the test program. By default, it relies on the Haskell RTS to find an
  optimal number. Set to 1 to disable parallelism.
- The TEST-ARGS variable can be used to pass arguments to the test
  program.
- Travis CI uses the new infrasctructure. It uses `travis_wait`
  to prevent timeouts because cabal only prints the output when
  the test suite is done running.

Port the test infrastructure to Tasty

(This is WIP) [ci skip]

`runtest.hs` is replaced by `TestRun.hs`.
This program imports `TestData.hs` which holds the tests metadata,
then turns it into tests usable by Tasty.

The functional changes are the following:
- The tasty framework provides a pretty output by default
  (colors, individual timings, proper indentation).
  Tests can run in parallel but the output is still deterministic.
- Tasty.Golden does the heavy lifting,
  i.e. comparing outputs and measuring time spent.
- Output is captured through a pipe connected to a bash process running
  the `run` script for each test ; this is implemented by the `runTest`
  function
- Tests are organised in families, reflecting directories' prefixes.
  They are listed in `testFamiliesData` in `TestData.hs`.
- Each test must be registered in `testFamiliesData` under its own
  family.
- A custom option has been implemented to run the test suite with the node
  code generator. The list of compatible code generators for each test
  is provided in `testFamiliesData`.
- Tasty.Rerun provides rudimentary incremental testing. The cache is in
  the `.tasty-rerun-log` file, which is therefore added to `.gitignore`.

The previous Makefile in `test` has disappeared in favour of passing
arguments to the test program.

Note that this commit disables testing because a compatibility
layer for `cabal test` must be implemented first. This is necessary
because the test program requires external dependencies.
However, you should be able to run the tests with `stack test`.

Merge branch 'master' of github.com:idris-lang/Idris-dev

Record update by function application

Syntax for updating a record by applying a function to the current
value, using `$=`. The function given after `$=` is applied to the
existing value in a field, giving the new value of that field.
Examples:

`record { x $= f } rec` is equivalent to `record { x = f (x rec) }`

`record { x->y $= f } rec` is equivalent to
`record { x->y = f (y (x rec)) } rec`

`record { x->y $= f }` is equivalent to
`\rec => record { x->y = f (y (x rec)) } rec`

etc.
Build with GHC8 and trifecta-1.6

This gets rid of a lot of code. Much of it was generated with
the "derive" tool, but some of it wasn't. I tested compilation speed

[1]: https://github.com/Gabriel439/bench

Check file size before reading in readFile

readFile will only read up to the size of the file when it started
reading, which means it's total again.

fileSize may have overflow issues - later it would be better for this to
return an Integer rather than an Int

Totality checker mutual fix

Sometimes we'd miss that a function was partial because of checking in
the wrong order in a mutual block.

Deprecate '%assert_total'

This is for two reasons:

1. It is error prone, because if you edit the function, the reason for
assertion may no longer be valid, but it's no longer checked. Better to
be precise about why a function is asserted total using a combination of
assert_total, assert_smaller and (new) assert_unreachable

2. It is a very tedious maintenance burden.

Reason 1 is the good reason. Reason 2 is why I actually did this.

Display of lifted types

Run errReverse, so that we get the pre-normalised type synonyms.
This is mostly to avoid displaying IO', but perhaps there is ultimately
a better way of deciding how to display things which arise from type
synonyms.

It's not so much about injectivity, as that we need to be able to
retrieve the arguments, and we can only do that with type or data
constructors

The File Effect has been updated to take into account changes in
`Prelude.File` and to provide a 'better' API.

For the most part, the new API should be backwards compatabile with
the existing API. The only difference is the support for custom error
reporting was minimised, and the new API returns a custom error type.

The test `effects001` was updated to reflect changes in the API.

Merge pull request #3204 from jfdm/more-pkg-info

Extend iPKG files to include metadata.

Extend iPKG files to include metadata.

Taking cues from cabal, the iPKG format has been extended to include more package metadata information.
The following fields have been added:

+ brief: Brief description of the package.
+ version: Version string to associate with the package.
+ readme: Location of the README file.
+ license: Description of the licensing information.
+ author: Author information.
+ maintainer: Maintainer information.
+ homepage: Website associated with the package.
+ sourcepage: Location of the DCVS where the source can be found.

The documentation for packages was also updated.

Store file with constraints + export

The file the contraint arises from is there to disambiguate universe
variables. Then we can export constraints in ibcs.

We don't yet load constraints in, however, because we're currently
generating an unnecessarily large number and it takes too long to check
the complete set.

Bind parameters as implicits in record functions

If we don't do this, then they won't get added as implicits unless they
happen to begin with a lower case letter.

Fix shadowing in let bindings

It's not *quite* a shadowing problem, but that is the effect in
practice: let bindings should only turn into case blocks if the left
hand side is a data constructor application, otherwise we might lose
some useful information.

Fixes #2740

Added %thaw directive

The opposite of %freeze, this allows a frozen definition to reduce
again. Only names which have previously been frozen can be thawed.

Testing Adjustments for Quicker Regression Tests.

Several of the regression tests have been consolidated into a single
test case: `regression001`. The names of the individual test~ files
have not been changed, and where appropriate the test files have been
given a new name, after the originating regression test.

The tests consolidated were those that only performed type checking,
and produced no output. The list is: `reg036`, `reg037`, `reg038`,
`reg046`, `reg047`, `reg053`, `reg057`, `reg058`, `reg059`, `reg060`,
`reg061`, `reg062`, `reg063`, `reg064`, `reg065`, `reg066` `reg071`,
and `reg073`.

Anecdotal evidence captured from individual timings places the savings
to be approx: *36s*. Pre consolidation the combined running time for
the tests was approx. 50.71s, and post-consolidation approx. 14.74s.

Further, anecdotal evidence captured from running the entire test
suite is suggests an even better saving:

+ *Before*: `Duration of Entire Test Suite was 825.442274s`
+ *After*: `Duration of Entire Test Suite was 770.619734s`

Overall time has been saved.

Updating the README.

+ Formatted the README using Markdown
+ Added missing categories

Fix ordering of dependent patterns/implicits

When we reorder automatically bound variables such as implicits and
pattern variables, we need to keep explicitly bound things such as pi in
the same order as they were given by the programmer. This rewrites
orderPats to do the job properly, and moves it to the elaborator
(Elab.Utils) where it belongs (out of Core.TT).

Set a limit on partial evaluation depth

There's reasonable situations where it could go forever if unchecked,
such as interfaces on nested types, where it won't stop because it
needs to specialise for each level of nesting. This limit stops it
elaborating forever.

Ideally it would also be looking for whether it had partially evaluated
the specific function - this limit may be a bit limiting for partially
evaluated DSLs.

Allow 'data' declarations in interfaces

This leads to a method and a top level function as normal, but
an implementation of the interface must define the method by returing
a type constructor (or some other injective function application).

The effect is that Idris treats the top level function as a data type,
which helps with unification and interface resolution.

parent implementation should be chased when resolving the constraints.
Also allow named implementations to be the privileged choice over a
block, with a `using implementation` declaration.

This is experimental, and the syntax and semantics might change...

Pass scope through to local interfaces

If we have locally defined named instances, they should have access to
names defined in the outer scope

This seems to confuse travis

Don't lose type information in interfaces

We've done the work of getting the types of the variables in the
instance head, so hang onto it, and we can push it into method types.

Change elaboration of interfaces

Instead of a function to build the dictionary with a where block, build
the method types, then the function, then the method bodies. This way,
the method bodies can use the reduction behaviour of other methods,
which they couldn't before as the methods were defined before the
dictionary.

Elaboration of local applications

Expand application of local variables to all of their arguments in one
go, where their type is known. This is better for type-directed
disambiguation, and for reporting errors more accurately.

Lazy elaboration tweaks

Firstly, never add a Delay to a pattern variable on the lhs, since
evaluation isn't forced until it is deconstructed.
Secondly, "try" is supposed to return the first error if there's a
failure, but this wasn't happening in some cases. In particular, this
can make errors from Lazy elaboration surprising, so this is fixed.

proofs which get generated are not going to typecheck if they turn up
under some evaluation

type, because further information may reveal it's a valid overloading.

be tricky - let the elaborator do its job instead!

Use bit-pattern identity for Double


Change the conversion checker to use bit-pattern identity on Double
instead of the IEEE comparison that Haskell's Eq type class implements.
Previously, we had definitionally equal values like -0.0 and 0.0 that
could nevertheless be distinguished by programs. This breaking of
functionality allowed proving a contradiction.

Thanks to Ryan Scott for the tip on how to do the bit-pattern
comparison!

Generate rewriting lemmas for data types

If no rewrite lemma is specified in a 'rewrite' construct, and one is
available for the types in the equality, apply that.
Rewriting lemmas may fail to generate in some cases (I haven't yet
worked out exactly what the criteria are, and if we can fix it...) in
which case it fails silently, at least until the rewrite is applied.

The result is that, for example, rewrites on equalities on vectors and
other similar types can be applied without doing anything special.
Modify the way of finding rewriting lemma
Reinstate checking of rewrite result type

New implementation of rewrite

Not using the 'rewrite' tactic any more, but building an application of
a rewriting lemma with a predicate directly. This allows a new syntax:

rewrite [rule] using [rewrite_lemma] in [scope]

Where rewrite_lemma is any function of the right shape, so can be a
function used to rewrite dependent types rather than the default, which
is rewrite__impl.

More to do: the rewrite_lemma could be generated automatically for many
dependent types, also the predicate building needs a bit of polish, but
this already works for, e.g., rewriting vector functions.

Merge pull request #3074 from jfdm/remove-old-things

Various Updates

Extended syntax for 'with' blocks

EXPERIMENTAL: I'm not sure this is a good idea or how it will turn out
to affect some other things, but let's see how it works out.

This allow calling functions defined by 'with' directly (i.e., the
generated auxiliary function) by allowing the additional argument syntax
on the right hand side. For example:

data SnocList : List a -> Type where
     Empty : SnocList []
     Snoc : SnocList xs -> SnocList (xs ++ [x])

snocList : (xs : List a) -> SnocList a

my_reverse : List a -> List a
my_reverse xs with (snocList xs)
  my_reverse [] | Empty = []
    my_reverse (ys ++ [x]) | (Snoc p) = x :: my_reverse ys | p

The '| p' on the right hand side means that the with block function will
be called directly, so the recursive structure of SnocList can direct
the recursion structure of my_reverse.

Merge pull request #3071 from jfdm/fix-cli-and-pkg-options

Fixes #1448, Fix cli and pkg options

Allow certain CLI options to work when using iPKG files.

Fixes #1448, #499.

When building idris packages only preapproved command line options (if
specified) will be merged into the options list from the iPKG file.
These allowed options are placed at the head of the options
list.

The allowed options are:

+ Logging levels and categories
+ Default total, default partial
+ Warn partial
+ Warn reach
+ Location of IBC subdir
+ Location of import dir.

Idris also reports an error if non-approved options are
specified. This error message details the offending flags.

metavariables.

Merge pull request #2959 from ziman/monad-flatten

Add flatten to Monad.

Make coverage checking more conservative

If an argument is a non-concrete type (i.e. a function type which
calculates its type from other arguments) then we can't merely generate
all the possible patterns from existing patterns, since there could be
any number of constructors of types we haven't thought of.

We now take the conservative approach of checking the catch-all pattern for
such cases, so that coverage depends entirely on the other concrete
patterns being complete.

There is likely a more precise way to do this, but this more
conservative way is at least sound.

Fixes #1292

Display totality errors on type check failure

Instead of only displaying them if there are no other errors, since
totality errors can be the cause of other errors.

head or it won't work (there'd be no way to resolve such instances)

Fix behaviour of %hide

%hide now merely makes a name inaccessible to programs, without changing
any further behaviour. This is by adding a new accessibility class
"Hidden" which can only be set via a %hide directive, and only for names
which are currently visible.

(Note that this doesn't quite fix the behaviour completely, because
it'll behave oddly for names hidden in the current module. Will fix in a
future commit...)

Merge branch 'master' of github.com:idris-lang/Idris-dev

Conflicts:
	CHANGELOG

New rules for name visibility

Exported definitions can only refer to things which are also exported,
to prevent private names leaking into types. Public definitions can only
refer to other public things, since their reduction behaviour forms part
of a module's interface.
Improve FAQ answer on universes

Update Agda-style reflection test with quoteGoal

Hygiene in quoted names makes this work as it should.

Fix missing cases in Show for Const

New constructors were added, but the corresponding Show implementation
had not been updated.

Change export qualifier keywords

abstract is now 'export'
public is now 'public export'

This is mostly to discourage complete public export unless you really
mean it, since it means that the definition effectively becomes part of
the interface as well as the type.

Simplify export rules.

No longer have the default changing according to whether there are any
access modifiers in a module.

Syntax hygiene for resolved quoted names

When quoting a name that's locally bound by a syntax rule, resolved name
quotations should be renamed along with the binder. This allows syntax
rules to contain reflected references to names that they introduce,
which enables some nice metaprogramming idioms and, among other things,
makes an analog of Agda's quoteGoal expressible.

Canonicalize the set of loaded files for comparing watch events to.

Resolves ., .., and symlinks, though docs say symlink resolution doesn't
work on Windows.

For #2909
Bump supported async version to allow 2.1

Initial commit of integrating test suite to cabal build.

Cabal has the ability to run test suites, this commit allows the idris
test suite to 'run' from cabal. THe old behaviour is still left as is.

To run the test suite through cabal:

```
cabal test --test-option="<args>"
```

To run using stack:

```
stack test --test-arguments <args>
```

Initial commit for a category based logger for Idris.

Currently logging is based on horizontally defined levels across the
entire language infrastructure. This commit introduces vertical splits.

Logging statements record both the level the message is to be recorded
at and the categories it belongs too. No categories is an alias for
belonging to all categories.

The State record stores both the current logging level, and also the
categories to show.

Logging is decided if a given logging statement is at the right level
and if the categories specified are listed. By default all categories
are allowed, as levels will take care of logging statement visibility.

Make test script stack aware.

This commit adds some documentation to the test script file, and more
importantly makes the script stack aware.

When running a test, the script already checks to see how idris is
being built if a cabal sandbox is not being used an additional check
for stack is now made. If neither of the tools were used to build
idris then it is assumed that the default set up is used.

Bug fix for infinite loop while executing a callback in the Javascript runtime.

The NULL BC operation, which is supposed to clear a register (according to the docs) was translated as delete in the Javascript backend. This worked fine for clearing registers from the stack, but did not work well while trying to clear i$RT. This cause an infinite loop in i$ffiWrap which was checking the return value should have been cleared but continued to hold its old value (essentially ignoring the delete operation). Callbacks work fine now in my tests.

Tutorial updates

Better inference for case blocks

Now look at the type of the patterns to infer what the argument type of
the new function should be. This helps if, for example, the scrutinee
function has some type which needs to be resolved to a specific type
class instance, and we can't do this from the scrutinee alone.

Fix regression with making class bodies

:ac should add a class body when given a class name, but a previous
change stopped this working. Test added to prevent similar accidents in
future.

Tweak desugaring rules for 'case' in do blocks

(Also for ?holes) If there's no binding, assume that the type being
returned by the case block or metavariable is ().

This makes it possible to use case and holes in the middle of do blocks
without any ugly hacks, and if there's no binding it's probably what was
intended anyway.

Parser parses clauses independently so there is no parsing error
in code like this:

    foo : Int -> Bool
    foo 1 | 2 | 3 = True
    foo _ = False

Elaborator can check if it sees with patterns but no enclosing with block,

Ignore SIGPIPE on the unicies.

Some UNIXy systems will produce a `SIGPIPE` signal when calling things like
`send()`, `sendto()`, `write()` - since there is no handler, this causes the
process to terminate unexpectedly. This change makes Idris ignore SIGPIPE, so
that an EPIPE error can be handled properly.

Better disambiguation with type class methods

Add %deprecate directive

Usage:

%deprecate [name] [optional reason, as a string literal]

If 'name' is used anywhere, display a warning that it is deprecated,
along with the message.

e.g. perhaps we should shortly add:

%deprecate Float "Use Double instead. Float will be removed soon."
Tidy up name warnings in Prelude

Change type of HVect.put/get/update so auto works

auto implicits need to go after the arguments they refer to, because
elaboration works left to right, and until we have better rules they may
end up solving things too early if we're not careful.

Currently: Proof search will start as long as no metavariables in the
goal type correspond to positions in the data type where an argument is
in constructor form (i.e., solving by that constructor would work
trivially, thus solving the metavariable too early).

Fixes #2656
Update Eff constructors to remove warnings

Consistency of implicit/pattern name binding rules

We've always said that the rules for binding names in patterns are the
same as the rules for binding names in implicits, i.e. a name beginning
with a lower case letter, not applied to anything, will be bound
implicitly, or treated as a pattern variable. This hasn't actually
always been quite true, even though it was supposed to be...

Correspondingly, added a warning for constructor names which may be
unexpectedly bound implicitly.

This patch changes the pattern binding rules so that it is the case.
Fixes #2653

Take care when calling allNamesIn

If we've expanded alternatives, the term could be very big, and we'll
get the same results if we call before expanding alternatives. If we do
need to know all the names a user has written in a term, call before
expanding the alternatives.

This addresses part of the slowness identified in #2657
Remove apparently unused iif directory

Display expected type of RHS in error messages

Also added %error_reverse annotations on IO so that IO related messages
are more readable. This improves the error in #2672.

Merge "add definition" and "add missing" commands

If a function already exists, then adding a definition will now add the
missing cases (so in general, \d in vim or corresponding commands in
other editors will now add all the necessary clauses for a covering
definition.)

Parse to line now reads whole definition

Instead of stopping at the first declaration after it reaches the line
it wants, stop at the first non-pattern-match, so that it still reads
the entire definition to avoid strange totality errors. This mostly
helps the vim mode, and :addmissing.

Test that IPKG rejects executable with directory component

This ensures it really is a filename, and prevents something unwanted like
telling it to write to ../something or /something.

This tests the new functionality added to support hyphens in filenames
(see: https://github.com/idris-lang/Idris-dev/issues/2721).

Add test that IPKG executable accepts namespaced identifier

This tests that the current behavior of Idris when parsing the target
executable name is preserved.

PParser.hs: filename: Explain failed parse with |fail|

This still provides misleading output from the parser about what it
was expecting, but does explain what the actual problem was:

    *Pkg.PParser> execout <$> runparser pPkg defaultPkg "foo.ipkg"
                  "package bar\n\nexecutable = \"invalid/filename\""
    Failure foo.ipkg:3:32: error: a filename
        must be non-empty and have no
        directory
        component, expected: space
    executable = "invalid/filename"<EOF>
                                   ^

PParser.hs: filename: Verify it is a non-empty filename

Using |guard| after the parser has done its work leads to unfortunate
error messages on parse failure, though:

    *Pkg.PParser> execout <$> runparser pPkg defaultPkg "foo.ipkg"
                  "package bar\n\nexecutable = \"invalid/filename\""
    Failure foo.ipkg:3:32: error: expected: space
    executable = "invalid/filename"<EOF>
                                   ^

PParser.hs: filename: Restore backwards compatibility

We've used iName to parse the executable filename till now.
This change ensures we don't break any extant IPKG files.

PParser.hs: filename: Remove use of |try|

There's no need to rewind consumed input here should parsing fail,
so there's no need for |try|.

Thanks @david-christiansen for pointing this out.

Remove advice to import Language.Reflection.Elab

This no longer applies as of HEAD, as pointed out by @david-christiansen,
because the Prelude now includes this namespace.

Replace the advice with a tip to :browse the Tactics module to see the list of
tactics prior to entering the elab shell.

Drop claim that general-purpose commands are general REPL commands

:e at least is not, as pointed out by @david-christiansen.
Remove duplicated phrase

Fix typo: reply -> REPL

Thanks to @david-christiansen for catching this.

Rename record fields in reflection

Now, there is more overloading, but we get simpler, more memorable names
as a result.
CONTRIBUTING.md: Fix typo "Factroy" -> "Factory"

PParser.hs: Parse executable clause argument as filename

Previously, it was parsed as an iName, AKA a possibly-namespaced identifier.

This meant you could have dots in your executable's name, but no hyphens!

See: #2721: Allow dashes in package names
(https://github.com/idris-lang/Idris-dev/issues/2721)

PParser.hs: Add |filename| parser

As it stands, it reads in either a (possibly namespaced) identifier,
which was the old behavior, or a double-quoted string, which is the new
behavior.

This could be improved by actually testing that it's returning a filename,
but I'm clumsy with the parser abstraction, and it wasn't clear to me
from the Trifecta docs I looked through how to pass it through
System.FilePath.takeFileName and then enforce that it was a non-empty string.

Update the list of elaboration shell commands

Cover all and only the commands understood by |parseElabShellStep|,
defined in ParseShell.hs.

The previous list omitted some commands and included others that no longer
were available.

Also:

- Groups the commands (general, view proof state, alter proof state)
- Adds an intro summarizing how interactive proving works at a high level.
- Advises the reader to pull in the `Language.Reflection.Elab` module
  _before_ entering the elaboration shell.

Removes :q alias for :abandon

As of Idris v0.9.19, :q is no longer accepted by the elab shell.

Rephrases section "Interactively building elaboration scripts"

- Bullets converted to sentences rather than quasi-definition-list format.
- Aliases merged into a single bullet.
- Intro rewritten to introduce `:m` command before the `:elab` command.
- `:elab` introduced with its argument, as shown in the Idris REPL help.

Friendlier error on proof search failure

Now, proof search doesn't throw an INTERNAL ERROR when called on a goal
that isn't a datatype. Instead, it provides the following message:

    Prover error: Attempted to find an element of type Nat -> Bool using
    proof search, but proof search only works on datatypes with
    constructors.

When the goal is a function type, which seems to be a likely reason why
it would fail, it adds the sentence:

    In particular, function types are not supported.

Additionally, a variant of the Msg constructor for errors, called
FancyMsg, was introduced. This allows the use of the ErrorReportPart
type to define custom messages.

Fixes #2713.
Convert some datatypes to records in reflection

Add reflexivity tactic to Pruviloj

This is useful for _only_ solving goals that are equalities, which is
convenient when developing and testing certain kinds of proof automation
that should always produce equalities.

elaborator-reflection.rst: Fix rendering of bulleted list

reST requires a blank line before a bulleted list, otherwise it just renders
the whole mess as a paragraph with a lot of dashes in it.
Update docs test

Change documentation of map

Accurate as it is, it's not necessarily useful to explain concepts using
category theory terminology. Ideally, the documentation should give some
intuition for those not yet familiar with the concepts.

and Unit for write.  Upon failure the functions will return a user

Improvements to ipkg files for dependancies.

iPKG files have a new option `pkgs` which takes a comma-separated list
of package names that the idris project depends on. This reduces bloat
in the `opts` option with mutliple package declarations.

So rather than have:

```
package foo

opts = "-p lightyear -p containers -p tests -p pruviloj -p effects -p x --log 4"
```

we can now sayL

```
package foo

opts = "--log 4"

pkgs = lightyear, containers, tests, pruviloj, effects, x
```

Use elaborated form of cases to check for defaults

Before, the check for a default catch-all case was done using PTerm and
the Placeholder constructor. Now, universal cases at the end are found
by checking that all arguments are elaborated to pattern variables. This
can catch cases where it's not an explicit placeholder, and it avoids
confusion with constructors by checking the binders of the elaborated
case.

Respect quotation when expanding parameters

This keeps where-bound names from occaisionally failing in
antiquotations because they weren't expanded to where-names.

Merge pull request #2630 from david-christiansen/namesInQQ

Make name operations on PTerm quotation-aware
Add --package contrib to tutorial

Make name operations on PTerm quotation-aware

This fixes an obscure issue where certain do-bound names that did not
shadow, but were identical to, other do-bound names in different
subexpressions of one larger expression would fail when referred to in
antiquotations. Example:

    (do h <- gensym
        claim h a
        fill `(C1 ~(Var h)); solve) <|>
      (do h <- gensym
          claim h b
          fill `(C2 ~(Var h)); solve)

The second antiquoted h would throw a "No Such Variable" error, because
the second lambda-bound h was renamed at one point without its use site
being renamed similarly.

Pi binders can never unify with Type

Make this an unrecoverable error. This helps the coverage checker and
unification

Proof search fix

Check for metavariable application didn't actually look for arguments,
preventing some perfectly reasonable searches from happening. Two
regression tests added (under proofsearch00x)

Improve addImpl under PHidden

Under a PHidden we can't encounter new pattern variables, so make
addImpl aware of this. As a result, there's no longer any need to
qualify constant function names under a function application on the lhs.

Transform rules and constraints

Transform rules shouldn't be adding things to the global set of universe
constraints, since they have nothing to do with them. This turns off
universe constraints in partial evaluator generated definitions in
particular, which should not interfere with type checking of the rest of
the program.

Remove dubious matching rule

IIRC this was a hack for scoped implicits, but whatever it did isn't
tripped up in the tests any more and it's a horrible hack anyway, so off
it goes.

Injectivity assumptions

Parameters should only be assumed to be injective if they also happen to
be type class parameters, otherwise some things will type check which
otherwise shouldn't.

Change form of CHANGELOG

This new format divides updates into various categories, and makes it
much easier to write release notes. It's also useful to order by
approximate importance (but this is mostly subjective so not sure
it's worth trying too hard to do that.)

Better error when asking for non-existent goal type

Added top-level %runElab support

Now, %runElab also works in a declaration context, eliminating the need
for a useless definition of type () when running for side effects.

Move resolveTC to ProofSearch.hs

It is, in some sense, a proof search, and this means that auto proof
search can now solve things which require type class resolution.

One side-effect is that type class resolution will now only solve holes
which actually are type classes! So this may break code which was
abusing the type class resolution mechanism - such code can most likely
be rewritten to do proof search.

Fix coverage checker for sigma types

Using the old name meant it checked the wrong thing so always reported
covering cases

Tweak to hole lifting

Where the hole has a function type, it should display the whole function
type!
Merge branch 'hl-kw' into wip/tactical

Extra info for errors in advanced mode

When showing error context information, display the difference between
unification and conversion errors. This is convenient when debugging
Elab scripts.

Thread the fresh name counter through runElab

Before, recursive reflected elaborator invocations could lead to name
capture, because each recursive invocation had its own fresh name
counter. This made combining their results unsafe. Now, they share a
counter, which makes it safe again.
Better error when asking for non-existent goal type

Merge pull request #2494 from uwap/master

Make --mkdoc follow the sourcedir

Make --mkdoc follow the sourcedir
If you had an ipkg with a sourcedir defined before using the --mkdoc option would fail saying that some source files are missing.
This is because it didn't follow the sourcedir.

Proof search should only use user visible names

If they are implicits or class arguments, it's fine for 'auto' to see
them since they're only used internally, but interactive proof search
will give odd results if it uses them. So, we make a list of names which
proof search in interactive mode is allowed to use.

Make interactive proof search less enthusiastic

Instead of guessing, it will only fill in a metavariable if all of the
available constructors/hints have disjoint types. This means you'll no
longer always get 'Nothing' for Maybe or '[]' for List, but rather
you'll get a new metavariable.

'auto' behaves as before, because the idea there is to find any old
thing with the right type.

It feels like interactive proof search should be a bit more refined,
though, because the idea of that is to find the program you really want,
rather than any old program...

More refinements to this are likely, for example refusing to fill in
with locals if there are clashing types.

Tidy up 'tidy'(!)

Normalise the return type as well as th arguments.
Don't want newline after makeCase

Merge pull request #2449 from david-christiansen/parser-highlights

Semantic highlighting of implicit fromInteger

Semantic highlighting of implicit fromInteger

Now, editors get highlighting information for integer literals according
to the following rules:

 1. If the constant elaborates to a constant (such as the fromInteger
    implementations for Integer, Int, Bits8, etc), then the constant
    itself is used for highlighting informating, as it would be in the
    pretty printer.

 2. If the constant elaborates to an inductive datatype, the outermost
    constructor is used for highlighting (e.g., the Nat 4 highlights as
    S, and the Nat 0 highlights as Z)

 3. Otherwise, no highlighting is performed.

Highlighting for pairs, lists and sigmas

Now, the elaborator supports highlighting of pairs, lists, and sigmas in
their sugared for, revealing the underlying names in the highlight. This
means that tooltips in Emacs and any other editor supporting
highlighting can now show how a particular notation was disambiguated -
Vects and Lists give different tooltips, and pair types have blue
parentheses and commas while pair values have red ones. Likewise for
dependent pairs.

Merge pull request #2428 from david-christiansen/parser-highlights

Parser highlights

Make 'case' more flexible with dependent types

Implicit variables remain implicit in the generated case (or, more
accurately, variables which are unused in the rhs are made implicit on
the lhs), meaning that it is no longer necessary for each branch to
target the same type or for each case of the scrutinee to have the same
type.

In other words, case is now allowed provided that it does not affect the
form of any variable which is explicitly used in the case block.

Example, which is now allowed but wasn't before:

  app : Vect n a -> Vect m a -> Vect (n + m) a
  app xs ys = case xs of
                   [] => ys
                   (x :: xs) => x :: app xs ys

Parser-driven highlighting of quasiquoted regions

Now, quasiquotation and antiquotation regions are annotated by the
parser, which can help editors.
Parser-driven highlighting of quotation symbols

Initial parser-driven highlighting

For now, this provides highlighting for user-defined syntax
extensions. Eventually, the parser will provide more information about
the tokens and potentially the syntactic structure of the parsed code.

(input):Can't infer argument elem to Prelude.List.Nil
Idris> [] ++ []
(input):Can't infer argument a to Prelude.List.++,

Merge pull request #2387 from jgriebler/fix/repl-parse

Trim trailing whitespace in parseCmd
Simplify implementation of trim

Trim trailing whitespace in parseCmd

When auto-completing a filename to :load from the REPL, the trailing
space added by the auto-completion will be ignored for actually loading
the file, but a subsequent invocation of :edit will use the path
including the space, leading to the creation of a new file
"<module>.idr .idr".

This problem is easily fixed by trimming not just leading, but also
trailing whitespace in parseCmd.
