Merge pull request #2383 from david-christiansen/semantic-highlight

Fix implicit arg / function highlights

Fix error location in test

The syntax improvement has caused a more accurate location in an error
in a test.

Better approximation of syntax rule errors

External syntax is now properly used in error locations. Processing of
highlighting and non-highlighting FCs has been separated.

Replace absurd syntax rule FCs

Previously, FCs coming from syntax rules would keep the FCs of their
definition context. Now, after expanding a syntax rule, the FCs that
aren't contained in the region in which the syntax was expanded are
replaced by a reference to the present file.

This does not give a precise source location - that runs the risk of
generating false highlighting information - but this solution at least
places the error in the right file, and the "While elaborating ..." bit
can be used to find the error. We should probably get better at
separating the highlighting-relevant FCs from the
highlighting-irrelevant FCs in the future.

Stop overwriting case block pattern highlights

This prevents case blocks from getting their pattern clauses overwritten
by the name of the internal auxiliary function
Highlight postulates and their definitions

Preserve manual name type annotations

This lets highlighting code override the global state highlighting, for
example when emitting highlight information for something that's not yet
in the global state.

Fix implicit arg / function highlights

Before, sometimes implicit args were given the FC of their function
application. This caused them to sometimes overwrite the highlighting
information from their function when in a pattern position.

Fix dictionary arguments in dependent type class methods

Type class methods references were previously elaborated using the
ordinary function call elaboration, but their class isn't yet available
when the method lookup function is elaborated. This leads to a "can't
resolve type class" error on the type class definition.

Now, they have an explicit dictionary argument inserted, pointing at the
dictionary that's used for the type of the method whose signature they
appear in.

Fixes #2302.

Allow adding new effects in Eff programs

This is only allowed if there is a handler for all computation contexts
the program could run in. In particular, if the program is in 'Eff'
rather than 'EffT', then it is only valid for 'pure' handlers, like
State.

Note that, as a result, the effects a program can run isn't now limited
to the top level set of effects. In the case of 'pure' effects, such as
State or Rnd, I argue that this is okay. In the case of external effects
such as IO related effects, you can only add effects if the top level
context is impure. Again, I argue that this is okay - if you don't want
to add impure effects, keep the top level context generic.

Also added a test (by way of example) in effects004

Change disambiguation rules back

It's too restrictive to require type class resolution early, especially
for numeric types. For disambiguation to work, it needs a concrete type
error in all but the successful branch.

Tweak :exec to make it work under these rules.

Trying a new Effects api

Changes:
- Eff has become EffM, parameterised over (m : Type -> Type), which will
  allow us to introduce new effects later, though not currently used
- Eff itself is now a collection of type synonyms which build an EffM.
  It can take either one list of effects, a list of input and output
  effects, or a list of effects and a function to compute output
  effects; disambiguated by context
- EffT is as Eff, but takes the underlying 'm'
- Added 'sig' function for giving effect signatures.

All of the above mean we no longer need the {} syntactic sugar, though
it's still there. Old effect programs (should!) work with no or minimal
changes.

:exec can take an expression as an argument

This compiles the expression and evaluates it. It will either print the
expression (if its type is an instance of Show) or run it (if its type
is IO ()), or give an error otherwise.

Minor change to disambiguation rules

When trying alternatives, if elaborating the first introduces unresolved
type classes, consider this a failure and elaborate the second.
Normally, type classes should resolve as soon after application as
possible.

(aside: we need to write down precise rules for type-directed
disambiguation; they are not straightforward due to the possibility of
delaying type class resolution, auto implicits and unresolved
unification problems. There is a trade off between successful
disambiguation and efficient enough compilation, so we should write down
what the current trade off is.)

Replace the Monoid instance on Maybe

The current default Monoid instance for Maybe is like that in Haskell,
where a semigroup operator on the underlying type is used to collect
successes. Conor argues convincingly that this is not the right notion
of computation for Maybe [1], so I figured I'd fix it while we're young.

[1] https://www.reddit.com/r/haskell/comments/30s1t2/proposal_make_semigroup_as_a_superclass_of_monoid/cpvdco1

The old behavior is available in a named instance, and both are documented.

Merge remote-tracking branch 'refs/remotes/upstream/master' into wip/tactical

Add 'determining parameters' for classes

Also fix resolution rules so that determining parameters, in *all cases*
except Num instances (for defaulting to Integer), must not be
metavariables.

Syntax is:

class Foo a b c | a, b

the optional | a, b lists the determining parameters. When resolving
Foo, a and b must not be metavariables. c can be a metavariable (and
hence solved by type class resolution).

The overlapping instance check now only looks at determining parameters,
so, for example, for Foo the following instances would be considered
overlapping:

instance Foo Int Nat Bool
instance Foo Int Nat String

Docs forthcoming.

Sphinx Based Documentation for Idris.

Sphinx provides a retargatable documentation system for documentation, and code. Allowing for HTML, LaTeX, and ePub documents to be generated from a single source.
ReadTheDocs is a free service for Open Source Projects that provides continuous delivery of documents that use either Sphinx or MakeDoc.

This commit provides Sphinx based versions of:

+ The Idris Tutorial
+ The Effects Tutorial
+ Select articles from the Wiki to begin a language reference
+ Select articles from the Wiki to begin short guides.

The examples from the effect tutorial have been integrated as well.

In the `docs` folder see `README.md` for dependencies, Sphinx is easily obtainable from all major Linux ditributions and through brew on Mac OS X.

+ Running `make html` will produce a monolithic html website for use with readthedocs.
+ Running `make latexpdf` will produce individual PDFs for each of the above tutorials.
+ Running `make epub` will produce a monolithic epub. This will need to be adapted to either produce one of the above document sets, or individual epubs.

Future work will be to:

+ Integrate idris with readthedocs for documentation generation for tagged released..
+ Add latex and html generation to the travis builds.
+ Add

Change to a recoverable error in proof search

This means if a constructor fails when deep in search, instead of
abandoning the whole thing we'll just move on to the next metavariable.
This effectively gives backtracking for the 'search' tactic.

Of course, care is needed in choosing what to search for (make sure the
types are descriptive enough to cut off search, in particular), because
if it goes really deep this could take a long time!

Windows. This stops the output when an unicode character is reached. It's better

mintty it looks good. If the user has a terminal with latin1, there will
be some bad chars but they will see the entire text otherwise.

Merge pull request #1857 from david-christiansen/fix-monad-trans

Relax lower bound on mtl

New language-dependent FFI

More documentation to follow, but in brief:
- IO is now a synonym of IO' FFI_C
- IO' is parameterised over an ffi description, which explains which
  types are allowed in foreign calls, and what a foreign call target is
  (in C, that's a String giving the function name, for example)
- New function "foreign" for building a foreign call, given an ffi
  description, call target, and the type of the call. The type is enough
  to build a structure which the compiler uses to generate the call.

The type of main now needs to be IO' x (), where x can be any FFI
description.

There is currently only an ffi description for C; Javascript will
follow. FFI_C should also work for the llvm backend (it's really about
the calling convention, not the backend specifically). Small changes
will be needed to the various code generators.

Relax lower bound on mtl

This lets Idris work with a wider variety of mtl and transformers
versions. In particular, it causes it not to try to replace GHC's own
transformer's lib.

New way of dealing with unmatchable patterns

Any term which is not matchable, i.e. a function application or a
repeated variable on the left hand side, is automatically put in a
PHidden. The effect of elaborating PHidden t is to:

1. Delay the elaboration of 't' to the end of elaboration
2. When elaborating t, ensure that its value is already known due to
solving some other unification problem.

If something is PHidden, but not solvable by unification, elaboration
fails.
This finally fixes #323, and probably several other things.

Merge branch 'master' of github.com:idris-lang/Idris-dev

Fix visibility of imported things

Fixes #111
Previously, if a module B imports a module A, then a module C imports B,
the public names in A would also be visible to C (i.e. B would
automatically reexport everything from A). This seems to be a bad
default.

This patch changes the default behaviour so that the only names exported
from a module are those defined in that module. If B imports A and wants
to reexport everything in A, then A should be imported with the "public"
modifier (i.e. "import public A").

Several changes have been made to the prelude, since several prelude
modules were taking advantage of the old broken behaviour.

This may cause lots of things to break. Sorry. The fix is typically just
to import the module you should have imported anyway :).

A new primitive tactic for getting source locations

The tactic sourceLocation fills the hole with the current location in
the file. If such information is unavailable, it fails.

This is to be used by DSL implementers to provide useful error
messages that can't be caught at type-check time. Additionally, it may
prove useful for debugging and assertion libraries, so they can report
errors.

Because the tactic merely fills out an implicit argument in a particular
way, it doesn't break referential transparency, at least not of the core
language. This is similar to the technique used in Scala Virtualized.

Don't build Idris twice in CI

This is a pretty decent speedup. :) We need cabal register so idris-llvm
can find the Idris library to link against. Otherwise cabal will
helpfully resolve the dependency by downloading Idris from Hackage for
us.
Fix typo in comment

Pattern variables should be lifted to top level

...since pattern variables scope across the whole expression. If we
don't lift them, mysterious unification errors can happen for implicit
arguments.

Just store sorted list of syntax rules
Update CONTRIBUTORS

Optimize custom syntax rules

Previously all custom syntax rules were tried one after the other
with full rollback (via `try`). Now they are tried one after the other
but with a minimal rollback.

Introduces datatype SyntaxRules which contains a list of rules and
4 "precomputed" parsers (expr/simpleExpr * term/pattern). Every time
new syntax rule is introduced parsers are rebuilt. Expression parsers
use an appropriate parser.

Example: for the following 5 rules

    syntax "[" [start] ".." ...
    syntax "[" [start] "," ...
    syntax [from] "={" ...
    syntax [expr] "QED" ...
    syntax "if" [test] ...

previously resulting parser conceptually was

    choice [ try (symbol "[" >> expr >> symbol ".." >> ...)
           , try (symbol "[" >> expr >> symbol "," >> ...)
           , try (expr >> symbol "={" >> ...)
           , try (expr >> symbol "QED" >> ...)
           , try (symbol "if" >> expr >> ...)
           ]

now it conceptually is

    choice [ try (symbol "[" >>
                  choice [ try (expr >>
                                choice [ try (symbol ".." >> ...)
                                       , try (symbol "," >> ...)
                                       ])
                         ])
           , try (expr >>
                  choice [ try (symbol "={" >> ...)
                         , try (symbol "QED" >> ...)
                         ])
           , try (symbol "if" >>
                  choice [ try (expr >> ...)
                         ])
           ]

Profit is in transition between rules 1-2 (and rules 3-4):
if rule 1 fails after `expr` was evaluated it would have
been reevaluated again in the rule 2. Now it wouldn't.

fix for bugs in the bits primitive operations

See previous commit message for the explanation of the bug.

This commit gives the right fix for the bug, which is to take out the values
that you will need from the arguments before using the allocator.  The reason
is that the allocator may trigger a GC collection which will move your
arguments away. While you can use the resulting FWD pointer to get the data,
FWD values should never be used outside of the garbage collector.  The gmp
operations should be looked at to make sure it is not doing this.

In summary, any C code that uses the allocator should save any relevant values
that its pointers are pointing to first.

fix to some "obvious" bugs in BitsN primops

Ok, so many primops on 8, 16, 32, 64 bit machine words in the C runtime operate
by passing arg pointers to functions that begin by allocating a new VAL cell to
hold the result. If this allocation results in a GC collection then the
argument pointers may be pointing into the old heap, to a cell whose contents
has been overwritten with a forwarding pointer. While the collection algorithm
should update any references to these forwarding cells to the new cell, it
can't fixup the pointer you are holding onto right now "between instructions".

This bug happens when your operation is interrupted by the GC and you use the
forwarding pointer(s) as the arguments, resulting in incorrect results. This
would be hard to reproduce because it depends on the timing of the GC.

But the package idris-tf-random nonetheless can reproduce this if it runs long
enough, because it makes extensive use of BitsN operations. My canary program
at http://lpaste.net/112132 dumps the output of a Bits32 generator with a
static seed, but after a certain number of iterations (depending on GC timing)
the sequence will act differently from previous runs (depending on the value of
the forwarding pointers it is erroneously using). This commit makes the program
apparently deterministic again.

If you look at the GMP operations in rts/idris_gmp.c you will see in the
corresponding gmp ops, after the allocation of the result, the arguments are
retrieved using GETBIG which may follow this forwarding pointer.

Similarly I added four GETBITSN macros which either get these bits value
directly or get it from the forwarded VAL cell by testing if ty = FWD.
Operations in rts/idris_bitstring.c that do not do an allocation did not get
wrapped in this macro.

I'm planning to review GETBIG too, since it is recursive and the shortcut case
for INT (which does allocation) may suffer from this bug too.

Merge pull request #1541 from david-christiansen/pprint-more-annots

Pretty-printer improvements

Pretty-printing of implicit args to (=)

Now, the pretty-printer respects the "show implicts" option for
propositional equality. Demo:
```
Î»Î > (a : Type) -> (n,m,o : Nat) -> (xs : Vect n a) -> (ys : Vect m a) -> (zs : Vect o a) -> xs ++ (ys ++ zs) = (xs ++ ys) ++ zs
(a : Type) ->
(n : Nat) ->
(m : Nat) ->
(o : Nat) ->
(xs : Vect n a) ->
(ys : Vect m a) -> (zs : Vect o a) -> xs ++ ys ++ zs = (xs ++ ys) ++ zs : Type
Î»Î > :set showimplicits
Î»Î > (a : Type) -> (n,m,o : Nat) -> (xs : Vect n a) -> (ys : Vect m a) -> (zs : Vect o a) -> xs ++ (ys ++ zs) = (xs ++ ys) ++ zs
(a : Type) ->
(n : Prelude.Nat.Nat) ->
(m : Prelude.Nat.Nat) ->
(o : Prelude.Nat.Nat) ->
(xs : Prelude.Vect.Vect n a) ->
(ys : Prelude.Vect.Vect m a) ->
(zs : Prelude.Vect.Vect o a) ->
(=) {A = Prelude.Vect.Vect (Prelude.Nat.plus n (Prelude.Nat.plus m o)) a}
    {B = Prelude.Vect.Vect (Prelude.Nat.plus (Prelude.Nat.plus n m) o) a}
    (Prelude.Vect.(++) {m = n}
                       {a = a}
                       {n = Prelude.Nat.plus m o}
                       xs
                       (Prelude.Vect.(++) {m = m} {a = a} {n = o} ys zs))
    (Prelude.Vect.(++) {m = Prelude.Nat.plus n m}
                       {a = a}
                       {n = o}
                       (Prelude.Vect.(++) {m = n} {a = a} {n = m} xs ys)
                       zs) : Type
```

This fixes #1410.

Merge pull request #1492 from edwinb/unique

Uniqueness fixes

Don't pass used unique variables to metavars

We can't use them anyway, and the resulting application won't typecheck
if we're not careful to remove them.

Don't propagate unique names to 'where'

Doing so breaks typechecking, leading to nothing working any more...
passing them to lifted 'where' definitions counts as a use in the
typechecker, so *any* where clause will fail to typecheck.

This is an effect of how 'where' clauses are elaborated, and is probably
not the best behaviour (though it is better than the default which rules
our where clauses completely) so we should revisit it later if
uniqueness typing turns out to work effectively.

command which takes the following form:

this. See the codegen/ directory in the Idris-dev repository for

Merge pull request #1447 from jwiegley/master

Bump upper bound on parsers dependency
Bump upper bound on parsers dependency

Add %no_implicit directive

'implicit' is useful, but can cause problems when there are lots of
places implicit coercions can be applied. In particular, in Effects,
'lift' can be applied to each operation, and to the combination of
operations in >>=, so if there's an error the elaborator will try an
exponentially increasing number of things depending on the number of
>>=s.

This is a bit of an ugly hack, but it allows certain definitions (such
as >>=) to be non-coercible, so this exponential explosion doesn't
happen any more.

Merge remote-tracking branch 'upstream/master' into fix/master/arduino

Added rts/arudino/idris_main.c. It is similar to the standard idris_main.c except it does not attempt to handle argv/argc and it also calls the Arduino init() function.

Additionally, all the rts .c files are now included in the data-files section of the idris.cabal file. When using Idris to cross-compile, we need to recompile the RTS for the target platform. We do not know what platforms might be targeted in advance, so we need to have all the RTS source files available at compile time.

If EXIT_SUCCESS and EXIT_FAILURE are not defined (as is the case on Arduino), explicitly define them using standard values (EXIT_SUCCESS == 0, EXIT_FAILURE == 1). In the long term the RTS should be modified to not call exit directly at all since it does not make sense on embedded platforms. The calls to exit(EXIT_SUCCESS) and exit(EXIT_FAILURE). Should be replaced by macros that do something sensible on the platform.

Set IDRIS_ENABLE_STATS in config.mk instead of in idris_stats.h. stats are not supported on Arduino. Also make sure that when IDRIS_ENABLE_STATS is not set, the idris_stats.h does not pull in time.h as this header is not available on the Arduino platform.

Support multiple let bindings

This sort of thing now works:

  test : Nat -> Nat
  test n = let foo = n
               S k = plus foo foo
              in k

The bindings must be aligned, and the keyword 'in' (indented however you
like within the 'test' block) terminates the list.

Pattern match alternatives are also supported, for quickly catching
failures:

  test2 : Nat -> Nat
  test2 n = let foo = n
                S k = plus foo foo
                    | Z => 42
              in k

Type class resolution fix

Check whether any errors introduced by a match are unrecoverable, rather
than merely checking if any more errors are introduced. Otherwise, in
some circumstances (where other problems are resolved by the match) we
might get a type class resolved where it shouldn't be, leading to
mysterious errors later.

Fixes #1365

Better treatment of unbound implicits

Now uses the elaborator to generate any necessary extra bindings, using
the same machinery as pattern match elaboration. The end result is that
you no longer need 'using' in a lot of cases (it is still useful if you
want to give explicit types, of course). e.g. this now works as it
stands:

  data Elem : a -> Vect n a -> Type where
       Here : Elem x (x :: xs)
       There : Elem x xs -> Elem x (y :: xs)

  isElem : DecEq a => (x : a) -> (xs : _) -> Maybe (Elem x xs)

This should also reduce the number of weird "no such variable" errors
signfificantly. In particular, it fixes #1354

Merge pull request #1287 from david-christiansen/postulate-providers

Distinguish postulate providers and type providers at use site

Distinguish postulate providers and type providers at use site

This is not backwards compatible, but as far as I know, there are no
users of postulate providers who are not me.

The old system allowed both the definition of the provider and the use
site to be involved in the determination of what is a postulate and what
is not. This is not good - users should always be in full control of
this.

The new implementation has two syntaxes:

%provide (x : t) with p

%provide postulate x with p

The first is the type provider syntax we know and love. The second
requires that the provider in fact return a type, which is then made
into the type of the resulting postulate.

Add --testpkg option + tests section in IPKG files

Add a new section to IPKG files called "tests". This section should be a
comma-separated list of fully qualified names of IO actions, the
sequence of which in some way test an Idris package.

When invoked as idris --testpkg IPKG, Idris will generate a module in a
temporary directory that imports every module from the package IPKG and
whose main function simply executes each specified test.

The intention is to keep test specifications as low-level as possible,
allowing user libraries to define a better mechanism on top of this.

Two reasons:

1. The most important: it makes error messages *so much better* :).
Because "effect'" rarely properly fails due to having a very generic
type, so any error arises later and breaks the real error which came
from lift'
2. It is much easier to explain what's going on when documenting
effects!

Apologies for breaking effectful code: I now think it is much better
this way though.

Add :loadto command

Loads an input file up to the declaration beginning at the given line,
discarding any declaration after that.

This only really makes sense when developing interactively: it means you
can work on something at the top of a file without worrying about how it
affects what happens later (this also potentially makes it a lot
quicker!)

the proof obligations in Effects, so replace the old proof search (it's
also noticeably faster in larger programs).

Add :makelemma command in interactive editing

Given a metavariable and a line number, add a new top level function to
solve that metavariable, and fill in the metavariable with an
application of that function.

e.g. given

  plus_commutes : (n : Nat) -> (m : Nat) -> n + m = m + n
  plus_commutes Z m = ?pcrhs_Z
  plus_commutes (S k) m = rewrite plus_commutes k m in ?pcrhs_S

:makelemma on pcrhs_S will update the file to

  pcrhs_S : (k : Nat) -> (m : Nat) -> S (plus m k) = plus m (S k)

  plus_commutes : (n : Nat) -> (m : Nat) -> n + m = m + n
  plus_commutes Z m = ?pcrhs_Z
  plus_commutes (S k) m = rewrite plus_commutes k m in (pcrhs_S k m)

where pcrhs_S can be built interactively in the normal way.
Add primitive for stdout, stderr
Merge current master into fix/911- branch

Fix List.split

This commit makes List.split behave a bit more sane and elegantly.
Currently split has the following behaviour:

  0: split (== ':") "foo"   -> ["foo"]
  1: split (== ':") ":foo"  -> ["", "foo"]
  2: split (== ':") "foo:"  -> ["foo"]     (!!)

  3: split (== ':') ":foo:foo"   -> ["", "foo", "foo"]
  4: split (== ':') ":foo"       -> ["", "foo"]
  5: split (== ':') ""           -> []     (!!)

Cases 3 and 5 are the problematic ones. I would think they would result
in ["foo", ""] and [""] respectively. This patch gives split this
behaviour, it also gives split the nice property that the length of
(split ':' str) is (1 + the number of colons in str)

I've looked at the uses of split in the prelude and none of them seem to
be effected by this change.

Merge pull request #1189 from david-christiansen/apropos-improvements

Apropos improvements

Fix boolElim optimisation

It made assumptions about the form of Delay which have changed with the
new erasure, so wasn't being applied any more (it is a modest, but
noticeable, performance gain).
Document :apropos updates in CHANGELOG

:apropos syntax for binders

Together with space splitting, this lets :apropos be used as a kind of
dumber Hoogle. For instance:

```
Idris> :apropos nat -> string
Prelude.Strings.length : String -> Nat
Returns the length of the string.

Idris> :apropos fin -> string

Idris> :apropos fin -> plus

Idris> :apropos fin -> +
Prelude.Fin.+ : Fin n -> Fin m -> Fin (n + m)
Add two Fins, extending the bound

Prelude.Fin.shift : (m : Nat) -> Fin n -> Fin (m + n)
Add some natural number to a Fin, extending the bound accordingly

Prelude.Fin.weakenN : (n : Nat) -> Fin m -> Fin (m + n)
Weaken the bound on a Fin by some amount
```

Case tree building considers heterogeneous types

Previously, arguments with different types in each cases could have led
to run-time failure (or non-reduction at compile-time) since branching
takes only the constructor tag into account. Now the case tree compiler
orders the patterns so that this can no longer happen.

Add :refine (:ref) command for refining a hole

Like :ps, but instead of a recursive search, it simply applies the
function given and fills in other arguments *by unification only*.

(In particular, this means it will fail if any implicit arguments need
other arguments, rather than the return type, in order to be solved by
unification).

So, this will work:

append : (n, m : Nat) -> Vect n a -> Vect m a -> Vect (n + m) a
append Z m [] ys = ys
append (S k) m (x :: xs) ys = x :: ?append_rhs1

*testref> :ref 6 append_rhs1 append
append k m ?append_rhs2 ?append_rhs3

But this will not:

vZipWith : (a -> b -> c) -> Vect n a -> Vect n b -> Vect n c
vZipWith f [] [] = []
vZipWith f (x :: xs) (y :: ys) = f x y :: ?vZipWith_rhs1

*Vect> :ref 18 vZipWith_rhs1 vZipWith
?vZipWith_rhs1

...because unification alone is not enough to work out the implicit
arguments a and b (even if there is only one thing that will work, it
needs a deeper proof search to find it).

Only show documented arguments in :doc

This reduces redundancy, avoids showing internal names like __pi_arg,
and takes up less space. New output:

    Idris> :doc foldl
    foldl : Foldable t => (acc -> elt -> acc) -> acc -> (t elt) -> acc

    Idris> :doc id
    id : a -> a
        Identity function.

    Idris> :doc the
    the : (a : Type) -> (x : a) -> a
        Manually assign a type to an expression.
        Arguments:
            a : Type  -- the type to assign

            x : a  -- the element to get the type

being a value return value!)

e.g. (somewhat contived, but...)

  readInt : { [STATE (Vect n Int), STDIO] ==>
              {done} if done then [STATE (Vect n Int), STDIO]
                             else [STATE (Vect (S n) Int), STDIO] }
                             Eff IO Bool
  readInt = do let x = trim !getStr
               if (x == "END")
                  then pureM True
                  else do putM (cast x :: !get)
                          pureM False

pureM x is equivalent to with_val x (pure ())

Reverse the reversible errors while reflecting

This makes Eff error reflection much more readable.

Change + to | because | better reflects our intentions.
should have been in the last commit.

force tag_arity and ty to be uint32_t instead of system dependent int sizes.
remove #include <unistd.h>. Not all platforms provide that header, and it does not seem to be required anyway.

hack in idris_gc to force 16-bit/2-byte alignment for
allocations. Some embedded platforms, like the arduino/avr, support
byte-aligned pointers. However, that makes implementing tagged
pointers very tricky. So, instead we just force 16-bit alignment.

Syntax for failures  in pattern matching let/<-

  let pat = val | <alternatives> in x'

...becomes...

  case val of
       pat => x'
       <alternatives>

  do pat <- val | <alternatives>
     p

...becomes...

  do x <- val
     case x of
          pat => p
          <alternatives>

So in particular, large effectful functions can deal with failure inline
rather than having lots of nested case blocks, e.g.

main : IO ()
main = do [p, a] <- getArgs
                      | [p] => putStrLn "No arguments!"
                      | (x :: y :: _) => putStrLn "Too many arguments!"
          print (foo (Just (cast a)))

Skip unnecessary coverage checking

If the last clause in a definition contains only _, we don't need to
coverage check it. This vastly, vastly improves the speed of this defn:

fourTupleElems : TT -> Maybe (TT, (TT, (TT, TT)))
fourTupleElems (App (App (App (App p ty1) ty2) tm1)
                (App (App (App (App p ty3) ty4) tm2)
                 (App (App (App (App p ty1) ty2) tm3) tm4))) = Just (tm1, tm2, tm3, tm4)
fourTupleElems _ = Nothing

Skip unnecessary coverage checking

If the last clause in a definition contains only _, we don't need to
coverage check it. This vastly, vastly improves the speed of this defn:

fourTupleElems : TT -> Maybe (TT, (TT, (TT, TT)))
fourTupleElems (App (App (App (App p ty1) ty2) tm1)
                (App (App (App (App p ty3) ty4) tm2)
                 (App (App (App (App p ty1) ty2) tm3) tm4))) = Just (tm1, tm2, tm3, tm4)
fourTupleElems _ = Nothing

Add ManagedPtr type

A ManagedPtr is just like a Ptr, except it points to memory inside
Idris' heap, so doesn't need to be freed. This is useful when you need
to create a structure C side for interacting with a C library, but don't
want to have to explicitly free it.

Also added
registerPtr : (p : Ptr) -> (n : Int) -> ManagedPtr

This moves the n bytes pointed to by p into the Idris heap.

In a non-C backend, or one where memory is managed differently, it's
entirely reasonable for this to be compiled as a no-op. The FFI treats
both Ptr and ManagedPtr as a void* in C.

Merge branch 'master' of github.com:idris-lang/Idris-dev

Add assert_smaller function

assert_smaller x y evaluates to y, and asserts to the totality checker
than y is structurally smaller than x. This can be used to explain the
reasoning for totality if the checker cannot work it out itself. For
example:

total
qsort : Ord a => List a -> List a
qsort [] = []
qsort (x :: xs)
   = qsort (assert_smaller (x :: xs) (filter (<= x) xs)) ++
      (x :: qsort (assert_smaller (x :: xs) (filter (>= x) xs)))

The expression 'assert_smaller (x :: xs) (filter (<= x) xs)' asserts
that the result of the filter will always be smaller than the pattern
(x :: xs).

Using this is always preferable to %assert_total if the termination
argument can be explained in this way.

Move buffer offset handling into idris code

This simplifies the native code significantly, including removing GETTYs
at every Buffer-related function call, at the cost of:

* Needing to store an offset of 0 in cases where the old code could just
  refer directly to the struct Buffer
* Boxing of the offset
* When an append to a buffer requires an allocation + copy, all of the
  data before the offset needs to be allocated and copied too (as
  there doesn't seem to be a good way for the append functions to tell
  the idris code when the offset needs to be changed and when not)

I think the simplification outweighs the cost, but I don't have hard
numbers so YMMV.

Added %error_reverse annotation

On a function, %error_reverse hints that the function should be run "in
reverse", i.e. as a rewrite rule from right to left, before displaying
an error message.

On a data declaration, %error_reverse means that all functions with that
type will be implicitly set as %error_reverse functions.

EFFECT is now set as %error_reverse. So in the Effects library, this
leads to much nicer messages, e.g.:

Can't solve goal
    SubList [(FILE_IO (OpenFile m))] [(FILE_IO ()),STDIO,
    ('Count ::: (STATE Int))]

...rather than the fully normalised versions we used to see.

Performance/compiler temporary hack: %erase

This is a (temporary!) annotation for erasing implicit constructor
arguments which are not forceable, and would otherwise remain in
compiled code. e.g.:

  data Binary : (width : Nat) -> (value : Nat) -> Type where
         zero : Binary Z Z
         num  : %erase bit, v
                Binary w v -> Bit bit -> Binary (S w) (bit + 2 * v)

This would erase 'bit' and 'v' from the num constructor (w is already
forceable). If bit or v is required for any reason, compilation will
fail.

This is a TEMPORARY HACK (no, honestly, it is) until we have more
general erasure of implicit arguments (which is coming) but this is a
placeholder which is required for some existing examples. Use at your
own risk!

Note that any code which abuses this will fail to compile, so it is at
least sound...

Make $ built in operation, rename ($) to apply

Slightly controversial, but I think it is better this way.

Main advantage:
Plays much better with disambiguation (which doesn't work especially
well with HOFs since it looks at the goal type and the types of each
argument to disambiguate, and if a function is the argument to $ we've
lost some of that information). This will make elaboration quicker in
some cases. $ is quite handy notation and we don't want to discourage it
just because it slows down the elaborator.

Main disadvantage:
Very occasional use in HOFs itself. Hence the new function 'apply' which
does the same thing.

Merge branch 'master' of github.com:idris-lang/Idris-dev

A simpler approach to handling name shadowing

It's hard to get right, so there's no need to be clever (indeed there's
a need not to be clever). So just before elaboration (while adding
implicits and resolving global names) we traverse a term and rename any
binder which has already been used, inventing a unique name which is not
used anywhere else in the term.

Merge pull request #782 from jfdm/feature/pkg-check-only

Command line option improvements.

EXPERIMENTAL: Disambiguate names in a block

Syntax: with <names list> expr
In the expr, if there are any ambiguous names which are defined in any
of the modules in the <names list>, restrict the options to that list.

e.g.

*disamb> with List [1,2,3,4]
[1,2,3,4] : List Integer

*disamb> with List [[1,2],[3,4],[5,6]]
[[1,2],[3,4],[5,6]] : List (List Integer)

*disamb> with Vect [[1,2],[3,4],[5,6]]
[[1,2],[3,4],[5,6]] : Vect 3 (Vect 2 Integer)

-- Fails since both options work
*disamb> with Vect, List [[1,2],[3,4],[5,6]]
Can't disambiguate name: Prelude.List.::, Prelude.Vect.::

-- Succeeds since only one option works
*disamb> with Vect, Stream [[1,2],[3,4],[5,6]]
[[1,2],[3,4],[5,6]] : Vect 3 (Vect 2 Integer)

This is really intended for disambiguating more complex or awkward
things, e.g. (>>=) can be disambiguated as follows:

foo = with Effects do
         putStrLn "Hello"
         --- etc

Fix memory leak

It turns out that having H.catch around too large a block means that
state is retained. In particular, having the catch around a recursive
application of the REPL means that all previous states get retained! So,
be careful to scope catch blocks around the smallest possible block.

Default superclass intances

This allows code like:

    data Identity i = Id i

    class Functor (f : Type -> Type) where
      map : (a -> b) -> f a -> f b

    class Functor f => Applicative (f : Type -> Type) where
      instance Functor f where
        map f fa = ap (pure f) fa
      pure : a -> f a
      ap : f (a -> b) -> f a -> f b

    instance Applicative Identity where
      pure = Id
      ap (Id f) (Id a) = Id (f a)

    data Nat = Z
             | S Nat

    x : Identity Nat
    x = map S (Id Z)

Note the default Functor instance defined as part of the Applicative
class. This allows the Identity data type to omit an explicit Functor
instance and one gets defined from the Applicative instance.

This feature is largely copied from the approach done in She:

https://personal.cis.strath.ac.uk/conor.mcbride/pub/she/superclass.html

It basically does macro expansion of each default superclass instance
(e.g. Functor) when the containing class (e.g. Applicative) gets an
instance defined. Currently, default superclass instance definitions
are not type-checked, only their macro expansions are.

Default superclass instances are limited to being defined for types
which are syntactically equal to one of the superclass constraints.

Don't reset totality for non-total things

We recheck everything at the end of checking a module, but if things
are currently known non-covering, we're not going to check that again,
so resetting means that that information is lost. So better only to
recheck things whcih are currently believed total, now that we have
complete information about the module.

Add a Cabal library

Moves Core to Idris.Core

The library allows using the Idris' backend from other Haskell code.
For example, we could use Idris as a general TT compiler with multiple
backends:

    run :: Idris ()
    run = do
      let ddir = "libs" -- TODO: Use Idris.Util
      addImportDir $ ddir </> "prelude"
      addImportDir $ ddir </> "base"
      elabPrims
      _ <- loadModule stdout "Builtins"
      _ <- loadModule stdout "Prelude"
      pterm <- fmap (flip delab program) getIState
      elabDecls toplevel [makeDecl pterm]
      compile ViaNode "wow.js" runProgram

Everything but Main, Util, Pkg and Paths_idris is currently exported.

Add String offsets to VM

Now strTail just stores an offset into a string, meaning that it doesn't
need to reallocate or copy an entire string. Therefore traversing a
large string is now much quicker.

Note - this means the entire string gets GCed at once, so if there is a
large string but only a pointer to the end of it, the whole string still
needs to be stored. For traversal, this isn't really a problem, but we
may want to reallocate if the GC discovers there is only one reference
to an offset string.

More flexible type class instances (on functions)

Supports this sort of thing:

  instance Functor (\x => Int -> x) where
    map f intf = \x => f (intf x)

  instance Applicative (\x => Int -> x) where
    pure v = \x => v
    (<$>) f a = \x => f x (a x)

  instance Monad (\x => Int -> x) where
    f >>= k = \x => k (f x) x

Update CHANGELOG

Extend split/splitOnLine to cope with 'where/with'

Main interface is via 'splitOnLine'. Give a source line, and a variable
name, provides information of what each variable should be updated to in
resulting pattern clauses, in the following form:

  [[(name_a1, pattern_a1), (name_b1, pattern_b1), ...],
   [(name_a2, pattern_a2), (name_b2, pattern_b2), ...],
   ...
   [(name_an, pattern_an), (name_bn, pattern_bn), ...]]

where the name expands into 'n' possible patterns, and the names
'name_a', 'name_b' etc need to be expanded to 'pattern_a', 'pattern_b'
etc in the resulting patterns (due e.g. to dependency).

An interactive editor should probably just use this information to do
a textual replacement on the original pattern, expanding into 'n' new
patterns.

Record internal name of 'with' functions

Can look up by source file and line to get the internal name
and the number of 'with' arguments, so thatJ case splitting has enough
information to generate syntactically correct cases.

Change '!' syntax and semantics to be uniform

! now prefixes a simple expression (most likely a name or a bracketed
application). !x means that the expression x (of type 'm a') will be
bound using >>= in the current scope. i.e.

foo !x
becomes
x >>= (\tmp => foo tmp)

Now, instead of saying "missing '('", the parser says "missing parenthesized

Make the parentheses around a with-rule scrutinee mandatory

Right now, parentheses are required around any non-atomic expressions that are
the scrutinee of a with-rule. In practice, this means that almost all
expressions require parentheses, as with is typically used to introduce more
information that was not available in the outer pattern match.

In the standard library, the only place where with rules occur without
parentheses is in Data.Bits.

Making the parentheses mandatory vastly improves parser errors in case they
are forgotten, RE #166 .

Sample of current message:
./WithRule.idr:4:14: error: expected: "{",
    function declaration
foo x with x == 0
             ^

Sample of message with this patch:
./WithRule.idr:4:12: error: expected: "("
foo x with x == 0
           ^

Another minor efficiency gain in elaborator

Call updateSolved less often. Also cut down search in Effects to depth
of 20 (this still needs to be done better, but it seems to have a large
effect on typechecking time for effects programs).

Reorder goal search for efficiency

Better to search first in places where the goal is most likely to be!

Running `make -j16 test` now runs tests in batches of 16.  This takes 1m
(real) (6m user), whereas `make -j1 test` takes about 5 minutes (both
real and user).  There is a bit of funniness with cancelling `make -j16
test`; I get a bunch of directory/file not found errors.  I'm not sure
why.

I've changed the test printing format a bit; make, unlike, say, the
ninja buildsystem, interleaves outputs rather than buffering them.  I
chose to make sure that the perl script printed entire lines at one,
resulting in output like
```
Running test004...
Ran test004...success
Running test005...
Ran test005...success
Running test006...
Ran test006...success
Running test007...
```
rather than
```
Running test004...success
Running test005...success
Running test006...success
Running test007...
```
with the `success` appearing some time after the `Running testNNN...`
message.

Add %specialise annotation for functions (Part 1 of partial evaluation)
%specialise [n1 t1, n2 t2 ...]
as an annotation before a function type means that the r.h.s. of all
the clauses will be evaluated, but with the name n1 reduced at most
t1 times, etc. The t1 part is optional, and means unlimited (which is
the default for all names at the minute anyway)

e.g.

%specialise [interp, fact 1]
i_factorial : Int -> Int
i_factorial x = interp [] fact x

will run the interpreter on fact, ensuring that fact is only unfolded once
to avoid infinite evalution.

The UK specific spelling is intentional :).

ensures they are at run-time. It's safe just to return an erased term
since it can't be inspected. Fixes #416

something is sufficiently higher order that the unused argument checker
doesn't feel it is safe to erase.)

Update CHANGELOG to reflect recent additions and fixes

Integer literals for Fin
If the elaborator can construct a proof that it is within bounds,
integet literals can be used for Fins. Otherwise, a cryptic error
message will be given.

Added %unifyLog construct
For debugging purposes
%unifyLof t will give a trace of unification problems while elaborating t
Also, log levels 6 and above will give the trace

EXPERIMENTAL: Syntax for applying functions by expected type
"t <== f" applies a function f to arguments in such a way that it returns
something of type t. The <== is a placeholder syntax until someone comes
up with something better.
(Alternative: t by f, but that uses up a new keyword)
Remove old ifdefs for supporting base<4 since we require base>=4

Add scripts

This commit adds a new command-line argument to Idris that allows an arbitrary
expression to be run in the executor. Two forms are supported:

idris Foo.idr --opt1 --exec

causes Main.main to be run after loading Foo.idr, while

idris Foo.idr --opt1 --exec expr

causes expr to be run using the executor.

This can be used to run Idris programs without having to compile them, giving
a faster startup for quick tasks. It can also be used to test the behavior of
the executor against the behavior of compiled code more easily.

Special-case prim__believe_me

Because the unification of primitive ops required that primitives only work on
constants, believe_me needs to be special in both the evaluator and the
executor.

Unify primitive implementations between evaluator and executor

The executor now uses the evaluator's implementations of primitives, with a
few minor special cases.

Allow Execute to import primitives without cycle

The executor can now import Idris.Primitives without introducing an import
cycle. This involved moving elabPrims to the ElabDecls module.
Remove unused import
Make primitive implementations act on Const rather than Value

Remove "return" from Monad

Monad has Applicative as a superclass. The methods "pure" and "return" are
supposed to do the same thing. This change does the following:

1. Remove "return" from Monad
2. Remove "return" from all instances of Monad in the standard library
3. Define a compatibility function "return":

return : Monad m => a -> m a
return = pure

This enforces that "return" and "pure" do the same thing.

Add primitive type names to name completion

This is necessary because these are treated specially by the parser and are
thus not in the global definition context, from which name completion is
drawn.
Tiny further simplification of type provider elaboration

Further simplify of type provider elaboration

Nested "if" and "do" blocks have been eliminated.

Clean up implementation of type providers

The type provider elaboration has been made more readable and the supporting
Idris library has been simplified.

Make the type of ierror more general

Before, ierror could only be used where Idris () was expected. However, it
should be usable in any situation as it halts execution.

Allow type class constraints in 'using' clauses
e.g. if a using block is given as

using (C a b c)
    block

Then any declaration in the block which uses all of a, b and c in
its type will have the class constraint C a b c added implicitly.

See test027 for an example

Allow $TARGET to override libdir on the `idris --install` command.

Some way of installing .ibc files to a location other than datadir using idris --install is necessary for making a system package out of this.
I have a standard script for making an Arch Linux package out of a cabal package up at: https://gist.github.com/4158545

During the build step, it runs:
```
cabal configure --prefix=/usr -O
cabal build
```
and then during the package step:
```
cabal copy --destdir=/tmp/idris/pkg
```
Trouble with the current impl is, that last step calls the Makefile, which calls `idris --install base.ipkg`, which then tries to write into /usr/share/idris-9.5 and gets "Permission denied" errors.
That destdir passed to "cabal copy" is already being passed into the Makefile as destdir/datadir: $TARGET=/tmp/idris/pkg/usr/share/idris-0.9.5.
So this just gives a way of installing idris packages to a location other that datadir, if desired:
TARGET=$HOME/foo idris --install blah

Added 'parameters' blocks
Allows abstracting over parameters across a block of functions
and data definitions. Effect is to add those parameters to *every*
function, type and data constructor. Inside the block, no need
to pass those parameters, outside they must be made explicit.

Interesting side effect: local data definitions now allowed in where
blocks.

class and instance declarations are also allowed in where blocks,
but visibility is global and no parameters are added.
